revision.text:
=Luxembourg= * The first meter was installed in 1925. * All stamps are inscribed “LUXEMBOURG” or, during German occupation in 1940s, “LUXEMBURG”. * The stamps are grouped by appearance and function: :: A - horizontal rectangle with truncated corners :: B - rectangle with simulated perforation outer frame :: C - rectangle with ornamental, Greek style outer border :: D - rectangle with straight outer frame :: E - open, horizontal frank, without outer frame :: PO - special stamps generated only by post office machines :: OO - special stamps generated only for official government mail ----
---- ==GROUP A: Horizontal rectangle with truncated corners==
---- ====Sub-group AA: Inscribed “LUXEMBOURG”==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA1.jpg|left|550px]] '''AA1. Hasler “D106” ''' (FV-8), 1925. : Frank with inner box around value figures. : Value figures large, outlined. : M#s 101-107. : TM: nil : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 5c, 10, 25, 35, 50, 75, 1 fr, 1.25, 1.50, 1.75, 2, 3, 5 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 20c, 30, 40, 60, 70, 4 fr, 10 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA2.jpg|left|220px]]
'''AA2. Timbrographe''' (LV-9), 1929. : Nearly identical to Type AA1 but M# 201 only. : TM: nil : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 40c, 50, 70, 75, 1 fr [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$100] : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 5c, 10, 20, 30, 1.25 fr, 1.75, 2, 3 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$200] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA3.jpg|left|440px]]
'''AA3. Hasler “F22” ''' (MV), 1928. : Frank is wider than Types AA1 and 2, and the inner box around the value figures is not as tall. : M#s 101 up. : With “fr.” at left and “c.” at right of value figures. : TM: DC, SC or nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]0oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA4.jpg|left|560px]] '''AA4. Hasler “F22” ''' (MV). : Frank is large like Type AA3 but corners are rounded rather than diagonal. : With “FRS” at left and “CTS.” at right of value figures. : M# 113 seen. : TM: nil with date only : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA5A.jpg|left|390px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA5B.jpg|left|420px]]

'''AA5. Hasler “F88” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : As Type AA3 but without inner box around value figures. : Frank variable in size. : Spacing variable between TM and frank from very wide to very narrow. :::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. “fr.” at left and “c.” at right of value figures :::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. “Fr.” at left and “c” at right of value figures : TM: DC, SC, or nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳0oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳00oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]◇0oo (121) :::::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Meter number at left of TM as well as at bottom of frank (137) [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA6.jpg|left|375px]]
'''AA6. Hasler “F66” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Very similar to Type AA5 but the value figures are not as tall, 4.5 to 5 mm compared to 6 mm. : M#s 139 and 140 seen. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳00oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AA7.jpg|left|240px]]
'''AA7. Francotyp "A" ''' (MV), 1933 or earlier. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][Quite scarce, value unknown] : Similar to Type AA3 but meter number in 300 series. : The value figures are angular. : One seen, M# 301, without town mark. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 000 (or possibly [[File:MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]00) ---- ====Sub-group AB: Inscribed “LUXEMBURG” (German occupation stamps)==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB1.jpg|left|230px]]
'''AB1. Hasler “D106” ''' (FV-6), 1941. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : Provisional design. : As Type AA1, but country name modified by insertion of large “U” in place of “OU”. : M# 101 only. : TM: nil : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 1, 3, 8, 10, 12, 25 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB2A.jpg|left|280px]] '''AB2. Hasler “D106” ''' (FV-6). : Value figures with large “RM.” suffix inside large rectangle. :::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Meter number 102 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$15] :::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Meter number 103 or 105 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : TM: nil : Values: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 0,02, 0,03, 0,06, 0,08, 0,12, 0,25 '''NOTES''': * The values 0,04 and 0,20 were reported as used but this has not been verified. * Meter 106 exists but is known only as a proof. Values: 0,05, 0,06, 0,08, 0,24, 0,30, 0,40 '''NOTE''': Meter Type AA2 (Timbrographe M# 201) was modified for use under German occupation and equipped with values 0,03, 0,06, 0,08, 0,12, 0,15, 0,25, 0,30, and 0,40, No examples have been reported, and the exact appearance of the stamp is uncertain. [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB3A.jpg|left|320px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB3B.jpg|left|330px]]

'''AB3. Hasler “F22” ''' (MV), 1928. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : As Type AA3. : M#s 106, 108-113 reported. :::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. “Rm” at left and “Pf.” at right of value figures :::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. “RM.” at left and “Rpf.” at right of value figures : TM: nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]0oo :::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With date but not town mark at far left (113) [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB4A.jpg|left|400px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type AB4C.jpg|left|290px]]

'''AB4. Hasler “F88” ''' (MV). : As Type AA4. ::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. With large “RM.” left of value figures (118) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] ::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. With “RM.” at left and “Pf.” at right (112) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][Rare, value unknown] ::::::::::::::::::::: '''C'''. Value figures alone at center (115) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$15] :::::::::::::::::::: TM: SC or nil :::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ✳0oo ---- ==GROUP B: Rectangle with simulated perforation outer frame==
---- ---- ====Sub-group BA: Frank with crown and coat of arms in center==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type BA1.jpg|left|520px]] '''BA1. Hasler F22” ''' (MV), 1925. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$150] : Nearly square frank with crown and coat of arms inside oval with “LUXEMBOURG” curved around them. : Value figures at bottom between “Fr.” and “Cts”. : M# 113 below frank. : TM: BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]00 ---- ====Sub-group BB: Horizontal frank with inner box, inscribed “LUXEMBOURG”==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type BB1.jpg|left|585px]] '''BB1. Francotyp “C” ''' (MV). : Horizontal frank with large inner box around value figures and straight ornamental lines at sides and bottom between outer frame and inner box. : With or without S# high between TM and frank. : M# 301 up, with or without “F” prefix, breaks ornamental lines at bottom center. : TM: SC, DC, nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]00 (O) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 (A,G) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]000 (A) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000 (G) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆0.00 (G) :::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Date boxed :::::::::::::::::::::::::::::: '''b'''. Meter number boxed [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BB2A.jpg|left|385px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BB2B.jpg|left|445px]]

'''BB2. Francotyp “Cc/Ccm” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type BB1 but narrow to very narrow spacing between TM and frank. : Date figures with stops after D and before Y. : M# with or without “F” prefix. ::::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. M# unboxed ::::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. M# boxed : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆0.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆00.00 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BB3.jpg|left|370px]]
'''BB3. Francotyp “A9000” ''' (MV). : Very similar to Type BB2 but date figures widely spaced with stops after D and M. : M# with “F” prefix or without prefix, unboxed. : TM: SC, BIC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆0.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆0,00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆00.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000.00 (''M# 370 seen'') ---- ---- ====Sub-group BC: Horizontal frank with inner box, inscribed “LUXEMBURG”==== ---- ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type BC1.jpg|left|575px]]
'''BC1. Francotyp “C” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$50] : As Type BB1 but with "LUXEMBURG". : With or without impression counter number high between TM and frank. : M#s 301-312. : TM: SC, DC, nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]00 (O) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 (A,G) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point starburst.jpg|12px]]000 (A) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ◆000 (G) ---- ====Sub-group BD: Country name in curved ribbon at top==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type BD1.jpg|left|375px]]
'''BD1. Universal “MultiValue" ''' (MV), 1952. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$25] : Upright frank with doubled straight inner frame lines. : M# 501 with “U” prefix in box at bottom center. : “FR | CTS” below value figures. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] [[File:MeterCat 5-point asterisk.jpg|12px]]0oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BD2.jpg|left|380px]]
'''BD2. Universal “Automax” ''' (MV), 1963? [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : As Type BD1 but with “FRANCS” below value figures. : M# 500 up without prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=00.oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]=00o o ---- ---- ====Sub-group BE: Country name straight at top==== ----
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type BE1.jpg|left|380px]]
'''BE1. Frama “M/E” ''' (MV). : Square frank with straight inner frame line and large box around value figures. : M# 200 up at bottom. : Value figures thick. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.00 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BE2.jpg|left|370px]]
'''BE2. Frama “M/E” ''' (MV). : Horizontal frank without inner box around value figures. : M#s in 200 and 2000 series. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.00 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BE3.jpg|left|350px]]
'''BE3. Frama “EPS3000” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type BE2 but the value figures are much smaller. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type BE4.jpg|left|330px]]
'''BE4. Frama “Sensonic” ''' (digital). : Similar to Type BE2 but the value figures are taller, not as thick, and more closely spaced. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ==GROUP C: Rectangle with ornamental, Greek style outer border==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type C1A.jpg|left|525px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C1B.jpg|left|330px]]

'''C1. Postalia''' (MV), 1952. : Country name unframed at top, Greek-style border along sides and bottom with inner box around value figures. : Frank width variable from 26 to 27+ mm. : M# in 400 and 1400 series below frank. : Value figures narrow. :::::::::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Wide spacing between TM and frank :::::::::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Narrow spacing between TM and frank :::::::::::::::::::::::::: TM: DC :::::::::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.– [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00,00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000.– [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000,00 :::::::::::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Value figures with “FR” prefix [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C2.jpg|left|370px]]
'''C2. Francotyp-Postalia “EFS” ''' (MV). : Very similar to Type C1 but M# breaks bottom frame line, and value figures are slightly taller and more widely spaced. : Spacing between TM and frank ~15-16 mm. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000.– [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C2point1.jpg|left|365px]]
'''C2.1. Francotyp-Postalia “MS5/WK4” ''' (MV). : As Type C2 but frank is wider than tall. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C3.jpg|left|330px]]
'''C3. Satas “Rotary” ''' (MV). : Frank smaller than Types C1 and C2 with M# above lower border inside value box. : Date figures tall or short. : M# in 700 up. : TM; SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00.oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★0.oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★00.oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C4.jpg|left|310px]]
'''C4. Francotyp-Postalia “T1000” ''' (digital). : Frank quite similar to Type C2 but with narrower spacing and digital value figures. : M# in 40000 series. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000.– [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C5.jpg|left|390px]]
'''C5. Neopost “Electronic” ''' (MV). : Frank wider than tall. : M# breaks bottom frame line. : M# in 80000 series. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋000.– [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C6A.jpg|left|320px]] '''C6. Neopost “SM24/SM26” ''' (digital). : Very similar to Type C5 but spacing between TM and frank is much narrower. : The value figures are more closely spaced, and the date figures are shorter. : M# in 80000 series. : Meter number small. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C7.jpg|left|320px]]
'''C7. Neopost "IJ" ''' series? (digital). : As Type C6 but the date and value figures are closer to the top rather than centered. : The meter number is large. : M# in 84000 series. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type C8.jpg|left|320px]]
'''C8. Neopost ''' unidentified model (digital). : As Types C6 and C7 but the date and value figures are close to the bottom. : The value figures are more rounded than with Types C6 and C7. : M# in 87000 series. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- == GROUP D: Rectangle with straight outer frame==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type D1.jpg|left|390px]]
'''D1. Safag ''' (MV), 1948. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : Large horizontal rectangle with country name underlined at top and no other contents beyond the value figures. : M# 200 up below frank. : TM: BIC or nil : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type D2.jpg|left|380px]]
'''D2. Hasler “Mailmaster” ''' (MV), 1980. : Smaller than Type D1 and the country name is not underlined. : The meter number is centered inside Greek style ornaments at bottom. : M# in 100 and 1000 series. : With "F" preceding the value figures. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000.– [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.00 :::::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. Without "F" preceding the value figures [[File: Luxembourg stamp type D3.jpg|left|340px]]
'''D3. Secap''' (MV), 1991. : Small upright frank with breaks in centers of both sides. : M# in 600 and 6000 series at bottom. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.– [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000.– [[File: Luxembourg stamp type D4.jpg|left|300px]]
'''D4. Secap''' (digital). : Frank similar to Type D3 but with space above country name. : Value figures fairly large : TM: rectangle : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000 ---- ==GROUP E: Open, horizontal frank, without outer frame==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type E1A.jpg|left|375px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E1B.jpg|left|355px]]
'''E1. Pitney Bowes-GB “5000” '''series (MV). : Country name across top. : “POSTES” above value box. : Crown and coat of arms between TM and value box. : Date figures raised in relation to value figures. : Curled ornament at left and top right of TM. : M# with “PB” or “P.B.” prefix below coat of arms. :::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Coat of arms capped with wide crown :::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Smaller coat of arms capped with simpler crown narrow at bottom ::::::::::::::::::: TM: DC ::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00 ■ [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00 o [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00o■ [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.o■ [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E2.jpg|left|360px]]
'''E2. Pitney Bowes-GB “5000” ''' (MV). : As Type E1 but without crown and coat of arms. : M# with “P.B.” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00 o [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00.oo [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E3A.jpg|left|360px]] [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E3B.jpg|left|365px]]
'''E3. Pitney Bowes-GB “6900” ''' (MV). : Frank with frame line at top and left : Crown above left frame line. : Country name and “POSTES” much smaller than on Types E1 and 2. : Date and value figures on same level. : “Fr.” at left of value figures. : M# with “P.B.” prefix. :::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Low crown :::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Taller crown narrow at bottom : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋0.o0 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E4.jpg|left|395px]]
'''E4. Pitney Bowes-GB “6600” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type E3B but taller crown with larger frank. : Large “F” breaks left frame line. : M# with “PB” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.00 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E5.jpg|left|370px]]
'''E5. Pitney Bowes-GB “6900” ''' (MV). : Frank similar to Type E1 but date and value figures on same level, and the value box is much larger. : “–POSTES–” below value box. : M# with “PBE” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.0 0 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E6.jpg|left|375px]]
'''E6. Pitney Bowes-GB “6900” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type E5 but without inner frame lines around value figures. : The crown and coat of arms are larger, and the TM does not have curled ornaments. : A frame line has been added across the bottom, and a line (from the edge of the die?) sometimes appears along the top. : M# with “PB” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00.0 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E7.jpg|left|390px]]
'''E7. Pitney Bowes “A/B900” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type E5 but lower and wider. : M# with “PB” prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋0000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋000.0 o [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E7point1.jpg|left|380px]] '''E7.1. Pitney Bowes “Paragon” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type E4 but larger frank with smaller value figures. : Narrower spacing that with Type E4. : Without "F" preceding the value figures. : M# in 50000 series with "PB" prefix breaks the bottom frame lines. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E8.jpg|left|380px]] '''E8. Pitney Bowes “EasyMail” ''' (digital). : “POSTES” centered below country name at top. : Large crown over value figures at left. : M# with “PB” prefix and date at right. : Various numbers at far left below curled ornaments. : TM: Linear across bottom : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]≋0000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type E9.jpg|left|340px]]
'''E9. Neopost "IJ" series '''(digital), 2013. : Frank with "P&T LUXEMBOURG" at the top, Greek ornaments at sides. : Large M# at bottom center, without prefix. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]00000 ---- ==GROUP PO: Special stamps generated only by post office machines==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type PO1.jpg|left|325px]] '''PO1. Satas “P” ''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : Small upright frank with single line, simulated perforation border broken at center of sides. : Spacing between TM and frank ~15 mm. : Identification letter at bottoms of TM and frank. : Hour figure between TM and frank. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★000 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type PO2.jpg|left|270px]]
'''PO2. Camp''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] : Frank very similar to Type PO1 but with “POSTES” over identification number at bottom. : Narrow spacing between TM and frank. : TM: SC with ID letter at bottom : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000oo [[File: Luxembourg stamp type PO3.jpg|left|365px]] '''PO3. Frama''' (digital). : Horizontal frank with simulated perforation border around the right half and straight line border at top and bottom of the left half. : At left are the town and postal codes in panels at top and bottom. : At right are the country name and identification number at top and bottom. : Identification number with "P" prefix. : Date and value figures across center. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000.00 [[File: Luxembourg stamp type PO4.jpg|left|410px]]

'''PO4. Escher Group "Riposte" ''' (digital), 2007? : Rectangular value box containing "PORT PAYE" at the top. : Value box with country name above the box and "POSTES" below. : Large single circle TM contains two lines of text through the center, the upper line a series of number codes and the lower line the date and time. : Printed in black on self-adhesive label with yellow "P&T LUXEMBOURG" underprint. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]■ ■ ■ 0.00€ ---- ==GROUP PD: Stamp used for collecting Postage Due==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type PD1.jpg|left|350px]]
'''PD1. Postalia''' (MV). : Simple horizontal rectangle broken at top right by "LUXEMBOURG". : At center is a large "T" filled with hatch lines. : The date is at left, and the value figures are at right. : Without town mark. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 000 ---- ==GROUP OO: Special stamps generated only for official government mail==
[[File: Luxembourg stamp type OO1.jpg|left|380px]] '''OO1. Safag''' (MV), 1947. : Horizontal frank without complete outer border. : Country name underlined at top, Greek style border at bottom, crown and coat of arms at both sides. : M# and department name below frank. ::::::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Department name “GOUVERNEMENT” (200, 205, 207 seen) ::::::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. “CHEMINS DE FER” (201 seen) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] ::::::::::::::::::::: '''C'''. “ARMEE” (203 seen) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] ::::::::::::::::::::: '''D'''. “S.N.H.B.M.” (204 seen) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$20] ::::::::::::::::::: TM: BIC ::::::::::::::::::: V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]000 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]]0000



----
'''NOTE''': During the German occupation of WW2 at least one meter with stamp of unaltered German design was used in Luxembourg. It can be identified only by "LUXEMBURG" in the town mark. Examples seem to be quite rare.
[[File: Luxembourg German occupation stamp .jpg|540px]]




---- ----

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Stacygraff!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:42, 22 November 2011 (UTC)

revision.comment: Removing "European_Offshore_Wind_Deployment_Centre_in_Aberdeen_Bay.svg", it has been deleted from Commons by [[commons:User:Ellin Beltz|Ellin Beltz]] because: Copyright violation, see [[commons:Commons:Licensing]].
revision.text:
[[Image:Windmills D1-D4 (Thornton Bank).jpg|thumb|right|Offshore wind farm using 5MW turbines in the North Sea, Belgium]] ==History== :''Wikipedia Article on the ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_wind_power ''History of Wind Power'']
Besides transportation, the earliest known use of wind as an energy source was its conversion to mechanical power in Persia sometime between 1000-200BC. The converter was a vertical axis windmill that turned a millstone, which ground grains for flour production. This design was later brought to Europe possibly by the Crusaders and windmill abundance increased dramatically in the 1200s.<ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=NcMws2-N3BMC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=Persia+and+the+Middle+East,+the+horizontal+axis+windmill+spread+across+the+Mediterranean%0Acountries+and+Central+Europe&source=bl&ots=gKZf1qNjIm&sig=75zpgLK9qmpTN7r8r_OaEM8WON0&hl=en&ei=GDfMTpXFPIqCtgeZwNFz&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=history&f=false</ref> In 1888 Charles Brush designed and built the first wind turbine to generate electricity, which was stored in batteries for his household use.<ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=Mu6BBq3W4pQC&pg=PA10&dq=charles+brush+wind&hl=en&ei=nwbcTrG1D6bq0gGSsrjHDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=charles%20brush%20wind&f=false</ref> The system produced about 12KW and lasted about 20 years. In 1892 Danish scientist Dane Poul La Cour came up with the first modern design of the wind turbine based on the aerodynamic principles.<ref>http://books.google.com/books?id=o-5w_qVJG5wC&pg=PA6&dq=paul+la+cour+first+wind&hl=en&ei=cAfcTtW2POf30gG0ofjTDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=paul%20la%20cour%20first%20wind&f=false</ref>
==Alternatives to Electricity production== [[Image:Bad_Gir_Yazd_Dolat_Abad.jpg|thumb|right|Badgir in Dolatabad Gardens, highest in the world at 34m, Yazd, Iran<ref>http://wreeec2011bali.com/uploads/files/Iran%20Traditional%20Architecture%20and%20the%20use%20of%20Wind%20(2).pdf</ref>]] Historically, wind has been used in non-electricity generating technologies such as the [[w:windcatcher|windcatcher]]. Windcatchers have been used for many centuries to create natural ventilation in buildings in central Iran. The structure directs wind down into the building and pulls air out of the building from the opposite side. Inside the building there is usually a pool or a decorating water fountain. The rapid evaporation of this water due to the very low air humidity of the area can significantly cool down the building and act as a natural air conditioning system. Although windcatchers have long been forgotten to the extent that even people in Iran may not have heard of them, a comeback is possible. BBC reported a design of a zero emission home in 2007 claiming that it will set the environmental standards for all new homes in the future. One of the main components was a wind catcher for ventilation.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6735715.stm</ref>
==Benefits of Wind Energy==
While environmental pollution and the emission of [[w:carbon dioxide|carbon dioxide]] from the use of fossil fueld constitute a threat to health, the environment and sustainable economic growth, wind energy is a source of clean, non-polluting electricity. Wind turbines cause virtually no emissions during their operation and very little during their manufacture, installation, maintenance and removal. According to the [[w:U.S. Department of Energy|United States Department of Energy]], in 1990, California's wind power plants offset the emission of more than 2.5 billion pounds of carbon dioxide, and 15 million pounds of other pollutants that would have otherwise been produced.<ref>http://windeis.anl.gov/guide/basics/index.cfm </ref> It would take a forest of 90 million to 175 million trees to provide the same air quality. Moreover, wind energy can provide incomes for rural areas.
By 2020, taking [[w:EWEA|European Wind Energy Association]] projections that 180GW of wind energy would be generating 425 TWh per annum<ref>http://www.enerverde.eu/cms/download/factsheet_environment2.pdf </ref>, wind power will provide annual savings of:
• 215 million tonnes CO<sub>2</sub>
• 261,000 tonnes SO<sub>2</sub>
• 333,000 tonnes NO<sub>x</sub>.
==Political Factors== ==='''United States'''=== Wind power is a new industry in the United States, so its public exposure has been limited. With increased interest in renewable energy, news outlets are featuring more stories about wind energy. Despite this increased media attention, a study conducted by researchers Klick and Smith (2010) polled 600 people about wind energy and found that public opinion is weak<ref>Holly Klick, Eric R.A.N. Smith, Public understanding of and support for wind power in the United States, Renewable Energy, Volume 35, Issue 7, July 2010, Pages 1585-1591, ISSN 0960-1481.</ref>.
Wind power was part of the renewable energy platforms of the two major parties during the U.S. Presidential Elections in 2008 and 2012. The Democrats and the Republicans have recognized the potential of wind power as a form of clean energy, and in their 2008 election platforms, proposed government incentives and funding to increase renewable energies.<ref>http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=78545</ref><ref>http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=78283</ref> Four years later, in 2012, the Democrats continued to maintain their ambitious agenda on renewable energies, including wind power, while Republicans, no longer incumbents, have reduced their renewable energy statement to a few sentences, which encourages continued renewable energy development, but in the market without taxpayer funding. <ref>http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=101961</ref><ref>http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=101962</ref> Since renewable energy is a growing political issue, wind power will continue to be featured in national energy debates. <ref>http://www.democrats.org/democratic-national-platform</ref><ref>http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=101961</ref>.
==Technical and Environmental Issues== ==='''Supply and Storage Issues'''===
The best option for wind is as distributed power<ref> http://ahec.org.in/links/International%20conference%20on%20SHP%20Kandy%20Srilanka%20All%20Details%5CPapers%5CPolicy,%20Investor%20&%20Operational%20Aspects-C%5CC17.pdf </ref>. Electricity generated from wind power can be highly variable at several different timescales: from hour to hour, daily, and seasonally. Wind also tends to be complementary to solar. This means that wind energy is an intermittent technology that can be used only when resources are available. The intermittence of wind hinders the economic competitiveness of the resource, because instantaneous electrical generation and consumption must remain in balance to maintain grid stability.
==='''Cost Issues'''===
Even though the cost of wind power has decreased dramatically in the past 10 years, the technology requires a higher initial investment than fossil-fueled generators. Intermittency and the non-dispatchable nature of wind energy production can raise costs for regulation, incremental operating reserve, and could require an increase in the already existing energy demand management, or storage solutions.<ref> ^ "Claverton-Energy.com". Claverton-Energy.com. Retrieved 2011-12-02 </ref>
==='''Wind Turbine Technological Challenges'''===
The engineering challenge for the wind industry is to design an efficient wind turbine to harness wind energy and turn it into electricity. The evolution of modern wind turbines is a story of engineering and scientific skill. In the last 20 years, turbines have increased in size by a factor of 100 (from 25 kW to 2500 kW and beyond), the cost of energy has reduced by a factor of more than five.<ref> http://www.wind-energy-the-facts.org/en/part-i-technology/chapter-3-wind-turbine-technology/ </ref>
It is a big challenge to produce a wind turbine that<ref> http://www.wind-energy-the-facts.org/en/part-i-technology/chapter-3-wind-turbine-technology/the-technical-challenge-of-a-unique-technology/ </ref>:
* Meets specifications (frequency, voltage, harmonic content) for standard electricity generation with each unit operating as an unattended power station;
* Copes with the variability of the wind;
* Competes economically with other energy sources.
* Stands high fatigue.
==='''Environmental Concerns'''===
Although wind power plants have relatively little impact on the environment compared to fossil fuel power plants, the environmental issues include how the turbines appear in a landscape, the sound they make and their effect on birds and other wildlife.
====Noise====
Like all mechanical systems, wind turbines produce some noise when they operate. In recent years, engineers have made design changes to reduce the noise from wind turbines.
====Visual Impacts====
Because they must generally be sited in exposed places, wind turbines are often highly visible. They need to be in order to catch the prevailing wind and work effectively. Being visible is not necessarily the same as being intrusive. However, aesthetic issues are by their nature highly subjective. Proper siting decisions can help to avoid any aesthetic impacts to the landscape.
====Avian/Bat Mortality==== Bird and bat deaths are one of the most controversial biological issues related to wind turbines. The deaths of birds and bats at wind farm sites have raised concerns by fish and wildlife agencies and conservation groups.
*''Measuring the Problem'' :The ''Wildlife Society Bulletin'' conducted a study in March of 2013 that "estimated 888,000 bat and 573,000 bird fatalities/year"<ref>http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/wsb.260/abstract</ref> occur as a result of wind turbines in the United States alone. To put this death toll in prospective, 970 million crash into buildings, 175 million crash into power lines, 72 million die from pesticides, and 1 million die from oil and gas spills<ref>http://www.livescience.com/41644-wind-energy-threat-to-birds-overblown.html</ref>.
*''Legislation'' :In November of 2013 the United States government ruled that Duke Energy Corp. would pay a one million dollar fine after pleading guilty to killing 14 eagles and 149 other birds. This marked the first time in US history that government enforced environmental laws protecting birds from wind turbine farms<ref>http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/11/22/21581139-eagle-deaths-at-wind-turbine-farm-duke-energy-agrees-to-pay-1-million</ref>. This ruling may remain the only of its kind as the Obama administration announced just a few weeks later on the 6th of December that "it will allow some companies to kill or injure bald and golden eagles for up to 30 years without penalty, an effort to spur development and investment in green energy while balancing its environmental consequences"<ref>http://www.wcpo.com/news/national/following-duke-energy-ruling-on-eagle-deaths-us-extends-permit-for-killing-eagles</ref>. This decision did not come without opposition as environmental groups worry that the free pass will spark an increase in the number of bird deaths rather than encourage efforts to develop a safer wind energy farms.
*''State of the Art'' :A number of prevention methods have been suggested to lessen the impact of wind turbines on avian and bat populations. Some of the techniques include painting turbine blades with black or UV paint, tracking flocks with radar, manually shutting down turbines when flocks approach, and building turbines around common flight paths. Research into these prevention techniques is in its early stages as researchers attempt to identify both why birds are colliding with the turbines, and how to reduce the rate of occurrence.
==Health Concerns== ''Wind Turbine Syndrome'' :It has been argued that wind turbines can have an impact on human health and quality of life. "Wind Turbine Syndrome" was first brought up as an issue by Dr. Nina Pierpont, an anti-wind energy activist. In her book self-published in 2009, she attributes symptoms including sleep deprivation, headaches, dizziness, anxiety, and vertigo to the infrasound and low-frequency noise generated by wind turbines<ref>http://www.windturbinesyndrome.com/</ref>. Since Dr. Pierpont published her research farmers and townspeople from across the world have come forward claiming that do indeed suffer from these symptoms. <ref>http://www.awea.org/learnabout/publications/upload/AWEA_and_CanWEA_Sound_White_Paper.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.windpoweringamerica.gov/pdfs/workshops/2010/webinar_mccunney_wind_turbines_health_effects_presentation.pdf</ref>
''Critics'' :Proponents of wind energy such as the American Wind Energy Association (AWEA) and the US Department of Energy have countered these claims by citing studies that correlate these symptoms to annoyance and stress rather than physical health impacts. Critics also note that Pierpont did not use a valid sample size, she did not see her subjects in person, her work was not properly peer reviewed, and there were no recorded complaints prior to her study<ref>http://checksandbalancesproject.org/2011/06/10/nina-pierpont/</ref>. This implies that until further research is done into the phenomenon, "Wind Turbine Syndrome" cannot be used as the sole reason to impede wind farm construction. <ref>http://www.windpoweringamerica.gov/pdfs/workshops/2010/webinar_mccunney_wind_turbines_health_effects_presentation.pdf</ref> ''Other Causes'' :Shadow flickering has also been identified as a potential problem for those living close to wind turbines. <ref>http://www.aweo.org/windlincoln.html</ref> However, minimum setback distances can be implemented to prevent this.
==Public Attitudes== National opinion towards wind energy have been positive as the United States attempts to reduce carbon emissions through the increasing use of alternative, cleaner sources. A survey conducted by the American Wind Energy Association in March 2010 noted that 89% of American voters believed the nation should increase usage of wind energy. Additionally, 77% supported the implementation of a national Renewal Energy Standard (RES) that would mandate the amount of energy obtained through renewable sources.<ref>http://archive.awea.org/newsroom/releases/04-22-10_Poll_Shows_Wind_Works_for_Americans.html</ref>
===Nimbyism=== :''Wikipedia Article on ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NIMBY ''NIMBYism'']
Despite overwhelming support for the United States to switch to more renewable energy, the installment of wind energy technology across the nation continues to face strong opposition by people living near proposed sites. Local opposition towards wind energy can be described by an attitude known as NIMBY (not in my backyard). Nimbies are people who oppose an issue due the proximity of this issue to them, or who support a cause (e.g. wind energy), but do not want it to require any sacrifices on their part, much like a free rider.
For wind energy, these sacrifices may include the aforementioned issues in addition to other ones pertaining only to citizens living in the near vicinity to proposed wind turbines. Consistent with risk perception, studies have supported that persons living close to the site of a ''proposed'' wind farm particularly oppose wind farms due to a linear relationship between distance and risk perception. Similarly, people further away from an ''existing'' wind farm oppose further wind development due a lack of local experience to alleviate risk as seen in the below figure. <ref>http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.enpol.2006.12.012</ref> [[File:Public Opinion near Black Hill (BH) Vs. Public Opinion near Dun Law (DL).png|thumb|Adapted from Figure 1 in van der Horst. 2007: NIMBY or not? Exploring the relevance of location and the politics of voiced opinions in renewable energy siting controversies. based on data from Warren et al. 2005: Green on green: public perceptions of wind power in Scotland and Ireland]] Due to the disputed medical legitimacy of Wind Turbine Syndrome, it has been suggested that WTS was conceived by Nimbies to support their opposition to wind power development near their homes.
====Examples====
====Cape Wind====
[[w:Cape Wind|Cape Wind]], an approved offshore wind project located near Cape Cod, was initially proposed in 2001 by Jim Gordon and his company [http://www.capewind.org/index.php Cape Wind Associates], the project would entail the installation of 130 wind turbines in a shallow, high-wind region of the Nantucket Sound known as Horseshoe Shoal. The company claims that the wind farm would be capable of supplying 75% of the electricity necessary for the Cape and the Islands.
Following its proposal, [http://www.saveoursound.org/ the Alliance to Protect the Nantucket Sound] was founded. As classic Nimbies, this group believes that the Cape Wind project has the right idea, but the wrong location. They believe that Cape Wind would be detrimental to wildlife, the economy, public safety and the scenery. Two computer generated simulations of what the proposed wind farm would look like from shore show how opposing groups can use images to affect human perceptions.<ref>http://www.capewind.org/modules.php?op=modload&name=Sections&file=index&req=viewarticle&artid=9&page=1</ref><ref>http://www.saveoursound.org/cape_wind_threats/view/</ref> Although the two images are from locations the same distance away from where Cape Wind would be, it is obvious that the subtle differences are meant to persuade the viewer one way or the other. In addition to images, both groups support their arguments with what they claim are facts. These facts are then labeled as myths by the opposing side. Some of the most heavily debated issues are the price of the electricity, the effect on marine life and the visibility of the turbines on the horizon.
Coverage of Cape Wind has not only been limited to local news and blogs, but has also been in the form of popular media. ''Cape Wind: Money, Celebrity, Energy, Class, Politics, and the Battle for Our Energy Future'' was written by Robert Whitcomb and Wendy Williams in 2008. An unreleased documentary named [http://www.capespin.com/ Cape Spin] has also been produced.
====Donald Trump==== =====Golf Course Development===== In early 2006, Donald Trump purchased the private Menie Estate, [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balmedie Balmedie], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberdeenshire Aberdeenshire], Scotland with the hopes of establishing a premier flasgship [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Links_(golf) links-style] golf course as a part of a larger 1.6 billion dollar "resort featuring a second golf course, a hotel, luxury holiday homes and a residential village." <ref>http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/10/sport/golf/donald-trump-new-golf-course-in-scotland/index.html</ref>
From the onset, construction of the new course and planned development has received both awe in the natural beauty and design of the course from golf enthusiasts around the world and vile from nearby residents over environmental concerns. In May 2011, British filmmaker [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Baxter Anthony Baxter] released a documentary ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/You've_Been_Trumped You've Been Trumped]'' negatively against several controversial actions Trump took in establishing the golf course, including obtaining a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site_of_Special_Scientific_Interest Site of Special Scientific Interest] to expand the golf course. Since then, it has won 10 awards from film festivals and environmental documentary organizations, four-star movie reviews, critical acclaim by Michael Moore, Alec Baldwin and Scottish filmmaker Bill Forsyth, whose movie [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Hero ''Local Hero''] was cited in the film. While Trump tried unsuccessfully to stop its broadcast on BBC, the documentary received over 1.1 million viewers with high praise across the UK, leading to a second showing on BBC2. <ref>http://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/22/donald-trump-bbc-film-row</ref>
=====Scotland Against Spin===== ======European Offshore Wind Development Centre====== Established in 2011, The [http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/917/0118802.pdf 2020 Routemap for Renewable Energy in Scotland] set a renewable energy target of 30% of all energy needs by 2020. Leveraging Scotland's offshore wind reserves, the Routemap details "large scale development of offshore wind represents the biggest opportunity for sustainable economic growth in Scotland for a generation, potentially supporting up to 28,000 directly related jobs and a further 20,000 indirect jobs and generating up to £7 billion for the Scottish economy by 2020." <ref>http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Resource/Doc/917/0118802.pdf</ref> In March 2013, Scotland approved a development test area 2 kilometers off the coast of Balmede in Aberdeen Bay to test the performance of new wind turbine designs to be used in future wind projects in Scotland. Scotland approved the new center for offshore wind developers and logistics-specialized companies to develop and test cutting edge technology in Aberdeen, bringing in high paying jobs to stimulate the local economy and support the creation of jobs in wind energy across Scotland. In addition to serving as a test development area, the European Offshore Wind Development Centre (EOWDC) is capable of generating power for nearly half of all homes in Aberdeen.
=====Wing Whackers===== In October 2012<ref>http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20121003006477/en/Gaming-App-Approved-iOS-6-Wing-Whackers</ref>, [http://www.techstudios.net/ Tech Studios] created an app called Wing Whackers to "provide a fun and interactive way for children and adults of all ages to learn about birds, energy, and the environment while being able to actually support and save the lives of some of the world’s most amazing avian heroes." The [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Side-scrolling_video_game side scrolling video game] features multiple characters "heroes" (an eagle, an owl, a bat, a pelican, a hawk) that a user has to guide through a series of obstacles (power lines and wind turbines) without falling into the clutches of animals "nemeses" on the ground (a snake, a shark, and a boar).<ref>http://www.wingwhackers.com/our-mission/</ref> Immediately following its debut, Donald Trump [https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/257882636381483008 tweeted] about the game as an attempt to spread awareness of potential negative effects of wind turbines to dissuade the EOWDC.
==Conclusions== Several lessens can be learned from the social interface of the wind technology. *''Technological path dependence.'' Technologies can progress and develop in one direction and that direction or path becomes the focus of future development, and alternatives struggle for relevance. *''Feasibility of different technologies in different parts of the world.'' Not all technologies are suitable everywhere. Economic, cultural and geographical factors affect the implementation of technology. For example, wind turbines are economically feasible in windy places while windcatchers are only feasible in extremely low humidity climates. *''NIMBY''. People may support an idea in general, but when its drawbacks directly affect them they oppose it. Most people make decisions based on incentives, prioritizing personal benefits over public benefits. Technologies that offer personal incentives thrive, even if they are detrimental to the environment. We see this all around the world as people or businesses make decision based on maximizing profits and ignoring the environmental effects. To be successful in saving the environment we must develop technologies that provide personal incentives as well as environmental benefits.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Pediatricconsultants!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 01:06, 23 November 2011 (UTC)
