[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=40]]
==Annotations== '''Limits of the diaphane But he adds : in bodies. Then he was aware of them bodies before of them coloured ... Limit of the diaphane in. Why in? Diaphane, adiaphane.'''{{spaces|5}}Here Stephen is contemplating [[w:Aristotle|Aristotle's]] theory of light and colour, which is found in two of Aristotle's works: ''[[w:On the Soul|On the Soul]]'' and ''[[w:Sense and Sensibilia (Aristotle)|Sense and Sensibilia]]''.Gifford (1988) 45.
Thornton (1968) 42. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Sense and Sensibilia'''''[http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/sense/ Aristotle, ''Sense and Sensibilia'' §3 (439a18 ff.), translated by J. I. Beare] and [http://www.archive.org/stream/aristotledeanima005947mbp#page/n164/mode/1up ''On the Soul'' 2:7.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''We have already in ''On the Soul'' stated of Light that it is the colour of the Translucent [τοῦ διαφανοῦς], [being so related to it] incidentally; for whenever a fiery element is in a translucent medium presence there is Light; while the privation of it is Darkness. But the "Translucent" [διαφανὲς], as we call it, is not something peculiar to air, or water, or any other of the bodies usually called translucent, but is a common "nature" and power, capable of no separate existence of its own, but residing in these, and subsisting likewise in all other bodies in a greater or less degree. As the bodies in which it subsists must have some extreme bounding surface, so too must this. Here, then, we may say that Light is a "nature" inhering in the Translucent when the latter is without determinate boundary. But it is manifest that, when the Translucent is in determinate bodies, its bounding extreme must be something real; and that colour is just this "something" we are plainly taught by facts, colour being actually either at the external limit, or being itself that limit [πέρας], in bodies. Hence it was that the Pythagoreans named the superficies of a body its "hue", for "hue", indeed, lies at the limit of the body; but the limit of the body; is not a real thing; rather we must suppose that the same natural substance which, externally, is the vehicle of colour exists [as such a possible vehicle] also in the interior of the body.'' |} Stephen's translation of διαφανὲς (''transparent'', ''translucent'') as ''diaphane'' suggests that he is using [[w:Thomas Aquinas|Thomas Aquinas's]] Latin commentary on ''Sense and Sensibilia'' to try and make sense of Aristotle's obscure theory:[http://dhspriory.org/thomas/SensuSensato.htm#5 Thomas Aquinas, ''Commentary on Sense and Sensibilia'' §5.] and [http://www.corpusthomisticum.org/css01.html#81216 ''Sentencia Libri De Sensu et Sensato'', Lectio 6.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Commentary on Sense and Sensibilia''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''huiusmodi corpora proprie dicuntur perspicua sive transparentia, vel diaphana. Phanon enim in Graeco idem est quod visibile ... Concludit ergo, quod color est extremitas perspicui in corpore determinato: quod quidem additur, eo quod huiusmodi corpora sunt, quae secundum se colorantur.'' | ''Such bodies are properly called perspicuous or transparent, or also diaphanous, for in Greek means the same as visible. ... Accordingly he concludes that color is the limit of the transparent. He adds in a determinate body, because such bodies are those that are themselves colored.'' |} Aquinas makes similar remarks in his commentary on Aristotle's treatise ''On the Soul''.[http://dhspriory.org/thomas/DeAnima.htm#215L Thomas Aquinas, ''Commentary on Aristotle's On the Soul'', Book 2, Lectio 15, §428.] and [http://www.corpusthomisticum.org/can2.html#80508 ''Sentencia Libri De Anima'', Librum 2, Lectio 15.] The term ''adiaphane'' seems to be Stephen's own. Neither the Greek αδιαφανὲς nor the Latin ''adiaphana'' is to be found in his sources. The obvious meaning of ''adiaphane'' is ''the opaque'' or ''opacity'', which is what ''[[wikt:adiaphane|adiaphane]]'' means in French. (Stephen, and Joyce, read Aristotle in Paris. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nestor/026|026.04 ff.]]) Four lines below, however, Stephen refers to the darkness as ''it''. In Aristotle's text, ''darkness'' (σκότος) is defined as the ''privation of light''. See also Stephen's description of darkness on the next page as ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/038|the black adiaphane]]''. It is typical of Stephen to be fascinated by Aristotle's outdated and obscure theory of light and colour (and Thomas Aquinas's comments thereon), while having little or no interest in what modern science has to say about these phenomena. '''''maestro di color che sanno'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''master of those who know''.Gifford (1988) 45.
Thornton (1968) 42. This is how [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante]] describes [[w:Aristotle|Aristotle]] in the ''[[w:Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]'' 4:131-132.[http://www.archive.org/stream/inferno00aliggoog#page/n62/mode/2up Dante Alighieri, ''Inferno'' 4:131.] In Dante's Italian ''color'' can mean both ''them'' and ''colour'', which is what Stephen is currently contemplating. Language is [[wikt:protean|protean]]. '''''nacheinander ... nebeneinander'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''in succession ... side by side''.Gifford (1988) 45.
Thornton (1968) 42. Stephen is quoting from the long essay of 1766 ''Laokoon oder über die Grenzen der Mahlerey und Poesie'' (''Laocoön, or On the Limits of Painting and Poetry'') by the German art critic [[w:Gotthold Ephraim Lessing|Gotthold Ephraim Lessing]].[http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/6889/pg6889.txt Gotthold Ephraim Lessing, ''Laokoon''.] and [http://www.archive.org/stream/laocon00lessgoog#page/n272/mode/2up ''Laocoön'' §20.] Lessing was inspired to write this essay by the monumental sculpture in the Vatican known as [[w:Laocoön and His Sons|Laocoön and His Sons]] or ''The Laocoön'', which depicts the scene described by [[w:Virgil|Virgil]] in Book 2 of the ''[[w:Aeneid|Aeneid]]'', in which the Trojan priest and his sons are crushed to death by two sea-serpents, punishment, or so the Trojans think, for advising them not to accept the [[w:Trojan Horse|Wooden Horse]].[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0055%3Abook%3D2%3Acard%3D195 Virgil, ''Aeneid'' 2:199-233.] In comparing the sculpture with Virgil's verse, Lessing came to the conclusion that the visual arts (e.g. painting and sculpture) and the literary arts (e.g. poetry) should not try to emulate each other. Each has its own unique sphere: painting is spatial, insofar as the whole work of art is experienced in a single glance; poetry, on the other hand, is temporal, being recited or read from beginning to end over an extended period of time. The painter, therefore, should depict only such images as can be captured in a single moment, while the poet should depict acts and events, avoiding static descriptions: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Laokoon §16''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Wenn es wahr ist, daß die Malerei zu ihren Nachahmungen ganz andere Mittel, oder Zeichen gebrauchet, als die Poesie; jene nämlich Figuren und Farben in dem Raume, diese aber artikulierte Töne in der Zeit;'' | ''If it is true that painting, in its imitations, makes use of entirely different means and signs from those which poetry employs; the former employing figures and colours in space, whereas the latter articulates sounds in time;'' |} {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Laokoon §20''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Körperliche Schönheit entspringt aus der übereinstimmenden Wirkung mannigfaltiger Teile, die sich auf einmal übersehen lassen. Sie erfodert also, daß diese Teile nebeneinander liegen müssen; und da Dinge, deren Teile '''nebeneinander''' liegen, der eigentliche Gegenstand der Malerei sind; so kann sie, und nur sie allein, körperliche Schönheit nachahmen.'' ''Der Dichter, der die Elemente der Schönheit nur '''nacheinander''' zeigen könnte, enthält sich daher der Schilderung körperlicher Schönheit, als Schönheit, gänzlich. Er fühlt es, daß diese Elemente, '''nacheinander''' geordnet, unmöglich die Wirkung haben können, die sie, '''nebeneinander''' geordnet, haben ....'' | ''Corporeal beauty is the result of the harmonious action of various parts which can be taken in at a glance. It requires therefore that these parts should lie '''next to one another'''; and therefore things whose parts lie next to one another are the proper object of painting: this art and this alone can imitate corporeal beauty.'' ''The poet who can only describe the elements of beauty, '''one after the other''', abstains altogether from painting corporeal beauty as beauty. He feels that these elements arranged '''in succession''' cannot possibly produce the effect which they have when arranged '''next to one another''' ....'' |} See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/521|521.22-23]]. '''''Los'''''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Los (Blake)|Los]] is a character who appears in the [[w:William Blake's prophetic books|prophetic works]] of the English poet and mystic [[w:William Blake|William Blake]].Gifford (1988) 45-46.
Thornton (1968) 43. In ''[[w:The Book of Los|The Book of Los]]'', Los appears as a smith, with furnaces, an anvil and a hammer of adamant.[http://www.blakearchive.org/exist/blake/archive/work.xq?workid=b-los&java=yes William Blake, ''The Book of Los'', Plate 5, lines 20-22.] It is a simplification, however, to regard him as the creator of the material world. It would be more accurate to assign that role jointly to Los and [[w:Urizen|Urizen]]. In March 1912, Joyce delivered a lecture in Italian at the Università Populare in Trieste on the subject of William Blake.{{cite book |title=Occasional, Critical and Political Writing |last=Joyce |first=James |editor=Kevin Barry |year=2000 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=0-19-283353-7 |pages=175-182}} In the course of this lecture he quoted from another of the poet's prophetic works, ''[[w:Milton a Poem|Milton]]'': {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Milton 29:19-20[http://www.blakearchive.org/exist/blake/archive/work.xq?workid=milton&java=yes William Blake, ''Milton''.]''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''For every Space larger than a red Globule of Man's blood'' ''Is visionary, and is created by the Hammer of Los:'' |} See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nestor/024|024.07 ff.]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/178|178.28 ff.]] '''''Demiurgos'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') ''[[wikt:Demiurge|Demiurge]]'' is the modern English form of the ancient Greek [[wikt:δημιουργός|δημιουργός]] (''demiourgos''), the word [[w:Plato|Plato]] gave to the hypothetical creator of the material world.Gifford (1988) 45-46.
Thornton (1968) 43. In ancient Greek the word meant ''craftsman'', ''skilled worker'', ''maker'', ''creator'', ''artist'', ''master''. Plato first used the term ''[[w:Demiurge|δημιουργός]]'' in his dialogue ''[[w:Timaeus (dialogue)|Timaeus]]'', not as the personal name of a specific deity, but simply as a common noun meaning ''craftsman'', ''maker'' or ''fashioner''.[http://www.ellopos.net/elpenor/physis/plato-timaeus/genesis.asp Plato, ''Timaeus'' 28a.] The ancient Greeks did not subscribe to the notion of ''Creation from nothing'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/038|038.11]]); for Plato, the creator was a craftsman who fashioned the material world out of the already extant [[w:Chaos (cosmogony)|Chaos]], like the sculptor who turned a shapeless lump of marble into the ''[[w:Laocoön and His Sons|Laocoön]]''. Later schools of philosophy that were influenced by Plato (e.g. [[w:Middle Platonism|Middle Platonism]], [[w:Neopythagoreanism|Neo-Pythagoreanism]], [[w:Neoplatonism|Neo-Platonism]]) regarded the Demiurge as an important but subordinate deity. [[w:Gnosticism|Gnostics]] used the concept of a Demiurge to solve the perennial [[w:Problem of evil|problem of evil]].The Gnostic [[w:Valentinus (Gnostic)|Valentine]], mentioned by Stephen in ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/021|Telemachus]]'', is reputed to have included the Demiurge in his theology.[http://www.gnosis.org/library/flora.htm Ptolemy, ''Letter to Flora''.] [[w:Ptolemy (gnostic)|Ptolemy the Gnostic]] was a disciple of Valentine. In Joyce's time, the [[w:Theosophical Society|Theosophical Society]] used the term to describe ''the Supernal Power which built the universe''.[http://www.archive.org/stream/isisunveiledama03blavgoog#page/n44/mode/1up/ Helena Petrovna Blavatsky, ''Isis Unveiled'' 1:xxviii.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid Steelblue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nestor/036|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/038|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=41]]
==Annotations== '''the black adiaphane'''{{spaces|5}}See the discussion on the [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/037|previous page]] on '''Limits of the diaphane'''. '''''Basta !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Enough!''.Gifford (1988) 46. '''''Frauenzimmer'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''women''.Gifford (1988) 46. Originally the term was used when referring to women of the better classes, or ladies, but by the end of the 19th century it had acquired a pejorative meaning: ''wenches'', ''drabs'', ''slovens''. '''omphalos'''{{spaces|5}}(''Greek'') [[wikt:navel|navel]]. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/007|007.31]]. '''Aleph, alpha'''{{spaces|5}}(''Hebrew'', ''Greek'') The first letters of the Hebrew and Greek alphabets respectively.Gifford (1988) 46. '''''lex eterna'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''eternal law''. [[w:Thomas_Aquinas|St Thomas Aquinas]] discusses the various kinds of law in his ''[[w:Summa Theologica|Summa Theologica]]''. In the First Part of Part 2, Question 91, Article 1, he writes: {{quote|''... a law is nothing else but a dictate of practical reason emanating from the ruler who governs a perfect community. Now it is evident, granted that the world is ruled by Divine Providence ... that the whole community of the universe is governed by Divine Reason. Wherefore the very Idea of the government of things in God the Ruler of the universe, has the nature of a law. And since the Divine Reason's conception of things is not subject to time but is eternal, according to Proverbs 8:23, therefore it is that this kind of law must be called eternal ... the end of the Divine government is God Himself, and His law is not distinct from Himself. Wherefore the eternal law is not ordained to another end. ''[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2091.htm ''Summa Theologica.'']}} Stephen argues that God himself is bound by the ''lex eterna'', as this is nothing but a manifestation of God's reason.{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 47}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 45}} St Thomas discusses the nature of Eternal Law in Question 96.[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2093.htm ''Summa Theologica.''] '''omophorion'''{{spaces|5}}(''Byzantine Greek'') An ''[[wikt:omophorion|omophorion]]'' is the distinctive vestment of a bishop in the Eastern Orthodox Church.Gifford (1988) 48. Originally made of wool or sheepskin, the [[w:Omophor|omophorion]] now resembles a long broad scarf of white [[wikt:brocade|brocade]] decorated with four crosses and an eight-pointed star. It is worn about the neck and shoulders in such a manner that the ends cross on the left shoulder, one end falling to the knees in front, the other behind. As a [[w:Presbyter|presbyter]], [[w:Arius|Arius]] would have been entitled to wear an omophorion.[http://www.biblestudytools.com/lexicons/greek/kjv/presbuteros.html ''Strong's Concordance'' G4245.] In the Western Church, the omophorion evolved into the [[w:Pallium|pallium]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/037|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/039|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=42]]
==Annotations== '''a writ of ''Duces Tecum'''''{{spaces|5}}''Duces tecum'' is Latin for ''bring with you''. A writ of ''duces tecum'', or a ''[[wikt:subpoena duces tecum|subpoena duces tecum]]'', is a summons that requires a witness to bring specified documents when he or she appears in court to give testimony.{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 48}} '''Wilde's ''Requiescat'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''May she rest''.Gifford (1988) 48.
Thornton (1968) 47. [[w:Oscar Wilde|Oscar Wilde]] wrote this short poem in memory of his sister Isola. ''[[s:Requiescat (Wilde)|Requiescat]]'' was written in [[w:Avignon|Avignon]] in 1874, seven years after Isola died (23 February 1867, less than two months before her 10th birthday). It was included in the collection ''Rosa Mystica'' (1881). Wilde was twelve when Isola died and nineteen when he wrote the poem. '''''All'erta !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''On guard!'' ''Be vigilant!''Gifford (1988) 49.
Thornton (1968) 47. These are the opening words of [[w:Giuseppe Verdi|Giuseppe Verdi's]] opera ''[[w:Il trovatore|Il Trovatore]]'' (''The Troubador''). '''Ferrando's ''aria di sortita'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''[[w:Sortita|Sortita]]'' is a musical term for a principal singer's first entrance in an opera; an ''aria di sortita'' is the song the character sings when he makes his first appearance. ''Di due figli vivea'' (''Of two sons there lived'') is the ''aria di sortita'' of Ferrando, the Count of Luna's captain of the guard, in [[w:Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi's]] ''[[w:Il trovatore|Il Trovatore]]''.[http://www.aria-database.com/cgi-bin/aria-search.pl?opera=Il+Trovatore&a ''Di due figli vivea''.] The aria is preceded by a [[w:Recitative|recitative]], which opens with the words ''All'erta! All'erta'' (''On guard! On guard!''). ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/038|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/040|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=43]]
==Annotations== '''''Descende, calve, ut ne nimium decalveris.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Come down, O bald head, lest you be made excessively bald.''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 50}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 48}} Stephen has altered the opening words of the first prophecy in the ''[[w:Vaticinia de Summis Pontificibus|Vaticinia Pontificum]]'' (''Prophecies of the Popes'', Venice, 1589), which was spuriously attributed to [[w:Joachim of Fiore|Joachim Abbas]]: ''Ascende, calve, ut ne amplius decalveris, qui non vereris decalvere sponsam: ut comam ursae nutrias'' (''Go up, O bald one, lest you be made more bald, you who are not afraid to make your wife bald in order to nourish the she-bear's hair'').[http://schulen.eduhi.at/stift_kremsmuenster/vat/vat01.htm ''Vaticinia Pontificum'']
[http://www.archive.org/stream/siueprophetiaeab00joac#page/n37/mode/2up Internet Archive] The prophecy recalls II Kings 2:23-24: ''And he ([[w:Elisha|Elisha]]) went up from thence unto Bethel: and as he was going up by the way, there came forth little children out of the city, and mocked him, and said unto him, Go up, thou bald head; go up, thou bald head. And he turned back, and looked on them, and cursed them in the name of the LORD. And there came forth two she bears out of the wood, and tare forty and two children of them.''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2%20Kings+2&version=KJV King James Version] In the Latin Vulgate, the childrens' taunt is rendered: ''ascende calve ascende calve''.[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=2%20Kings+2&version=VULGATE Bibla Sacra Vulgata] Stephen's Latin phrase is based on the very first sentence of the ''Vaticinia Pontificum''. When he (or Joyce) browsed a copy of this work in [[w:Marsh's Library|Marsh's Library]], it is possible that he read no further than this. He probably first encountered Joachim in his reading of [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Divine Comedy|Divine Comedy]]''. In ''Paradiso'' 140-141 Joachim is described as ''il calavrese abate Giovacchino, di spirito profetico dotato'' (''the Calabrian abbot Joachim, endowed with a prophetic spirit''). When an earlier version of this episode was published in ''[[w:The Little Review|The Little Review]]'' in May 1918, the reading was ''amplius''.[http://www.archive.org/stream/littlereview05mcke#page/n41/mode/1up ''The Little Review''] See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/037|037.06]]. '''''O si, certo !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''O yes, certainly!''Gifford (1988) 51. In Italian the word for ''yes'' is usually spelt ''sì'' (or, rarely, ''sí''). ''Sì certo'', without the comma, means ''certainly''. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/039|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/041|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=44]]
==Annotations== '''mahamanvantara'''{{spaces|5}}(''Sanskrit'') This is an esoteric term used in Hinduism to denote a very long [[w:Hindu units of measurements|period of time]].Gifford (1988) 51.
Thornton (1968) 49. A [[w:Manvantara|manvantara]] is a period of time equal to the lifespan of a [[w:Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]]: 306,720,000 years. A mahamanvantara or mahakalpa is a period of time equal to the lifespan of [[w:Brahma (god)|Brahma]]: 311,040,000,000,000 years. :1 mahayuga = 4,320,000 years :71 mahayugas = 1 manvantara = 306,720,000 years :2000 mahayugas = 1 day and night of Brahma = 8,640,000,000 years :720,000 mahayugas = 1 year of Brahma = 3,110,400,000,000 years :100 years of Brahma = 1 mahamanvantara = 311,040,000,000,000 years. In the context of ''Ulysses'', the meaning assigned to the term ''mahamanvantara'' in the theosophy of [[w:Helena Blavatsky|Helena Blavatsky]] is probably of greater relevance. In a glossary of theosophical terms, which Blavatsky appended to the 1890 edition of ''The Key to Theosophy'', the entries for ''Mahamanvantara'' and ''Manvantara'' are as follows:[http://www.archive.org/stream/keytotheosophybe00blav#page/299/mode/1up Helena Blavatsky, ''The Key to Theosophy'' 299, 301.] {{quote|'''Mahâmanvantara''' (''Sans.'') The great interludes between the ''Manus'', the period of universal activity. ''Manvantara'' here implies simply a period of activity, as opposed to ''praylaya'' or rest, without reference to the length of the cycle.}} {{quote|'''Manvantara''' (''Sans.'') A period of manifestation, as opposed to ''pralaya'', dissolution or rest; the term is applied to various cycles, especially to a Day of Brahmâ, 4,320,000,000 solar years, and to the reign of one Manu, 306,720,000. Lit., ''Manu-antara'', between Manus. (See ''Secret Doctrine'', ii., 68 ''et seq''.[http://www.archive.org/stream/secretdoctrines01blavgoog#page/n90/mode/1up Helena Blavatsky, ''The Secret Doctrine'', Volume 2, pp. 68 ff.])}} '''''— Qui vous a mis dans cette fichue position?'''''
'''''— C'est le pigeon, Joseph.'''''
(''French'') This is a near quotation from ''La Vie de Jésus'' (''The Life of Jesus''), an anti-Catholic novel by [[w:Léo Taxil|Léo Taxil]]:Gifford (1988) 52.
Thornton (1968) 50-51.
{{cite book |title=La Vie de Jésus |last=Taxil |first=Léo |year=1884 |publisher=P. Fort |location=Paris |page=15 |url=http://books.google.ie/books/about/La_Vie_de_J%C3%A9sus.html?id=auAuQwAACAAJ&redir_esc=y}} ::''— Who put you in this wretched condition?'' ::''— It was the pigeon, Joseph.'' In the original, Joseph actually asks: ''Qui donc, si ce n'est un homme, vous a mis dans cette fichue position?'' (''Who then, if it wasn't a man, put you in this wretched position?''). French grammar requires the feminine participle ''mise'' (''put''), as [[w:Saint Joseph|Joseph]] is asking [[w:Mary (mother of Jesus|Mary]]. But the error, which Stephen (Joyce?) replicates here, was already present in the edition of the book that would have been available to Joyce in Zürich.[http://www.robotwisdom.com/jaj/ulysses/nodding.html Jorn Barger, ''Joyce nodding?''] '''''lait chaud'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''hot milk'', ''warm milk''.Gifford (1988) 52. '''''lapin'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''rabbit''.Gifford (1988) 52. '''''gros lots'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''top prizes'', ''jackpots''.Gifford (1988) 52. Stephen, it seems, misunderstands this French term. He is referring to the public lotteries, which had been permitted in France since 1844.[http://www.archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri17chisrich#page/21/mode/1up ''Encyclopædi Britannica'' (Eleventh Edition), '''Lotteries'''.] But ''[[wikt:lot|lot]]'' means ''prize (in a lottery)'', so the actual meaning of ''gros lots'' is ''first prizes'' or ''jackpots''. '''''La Vie de Jésus'' by M. Léo Taxil'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Léo Taxil|Léo Taxil]] was the pseudonym of the anti-Catholic and anti-clerical French writer Marie Joseph Gabriel Antoine Jogand-Pagès (1854-1907).Gifford (1988) 53.
Thornton (1968) 50-51. ''La Vie de Jésus'' (''The Life of Jesus'', also known in English as ''The Amusing Gospel'') is a humorous work, in which Taxil satirically holds up to ridicule inconsistencies, errors, and false beliefs to be found in the gospels.{{cite book |title=La Vie de Jésus |last=Taxil |first=Léo |year=1884 |publisher=P. Fort |location=Paris |page=15 |url=http://books.google.ie/books/about/La_Vie_de_J%C3%A9sus.html?id=auAuQwAACAAJ&redir_esc=y}} '''''— C'est tordant, vous savez. Moi je suis socialiste. Je ne crois pas en l'existence de Dieu. Faut pas le dire a mon père.'''''
'''''— Il croit?'''''
'''''— Mon père, oui.'''''
(''French'') This is a fragment of a conversation Stephen had in Paris with Patrice Egan about Taxil's ''La Vie de Jésus'':Gifford (1988) 53. ::''— It's hilarious, you know. Me, I'm a socialist. I do not believe in the existence of God. You mustn't tell my father.''
::''— He is a believer?''
::''— My father, yes.''
'''''Schluss'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''Period!'' ''Enough said!''Gifford (1988) 53. ''[[wikt:Schluss|Schluss]]'' is German for ''end'', ''conclusion'', but here Stephen is using it colloquially as a mild exclamation, meaning ''Enough!'' '''Paysayennn. P. C. N., you know : ''physiques, chimiques et naturelles'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''physical, chemical and natural''.Gifford (1988) 53. ''Paysayenn'' is a phonetic spelling of how a Frenchman would pronounce the letters ''[[w:French alphabet|P. C. N.]]'' The letters are an abbreviation for the French phrase ''[[w:fr:PCN|Physique-Chimie-Sciences naturelles]]'' (''Physics, Chemistry, Natural Science''). In December 1902, Joyce was granted a provisional card of admission to the course for the certificate in physics, chemistry and biology at the École de Médecine in Paris. This certificate was required before he would be permitted to study medicine. As it happened, his medical ambitions only lasted a few more days.Ellmann (1982) 112-113. Note that Stephen's translation of ''P. C. N.'' is not quite correct. '''''mou en civet'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''lung stew''.Gifford (1988) 53. A stew made from the lungs or [[wikt:lights|lights]] of butchered animals would have been one of the cheapest dishes available in a Paris restaurant. '''''boul'Mich''''''{{spaces|5}}(''French slang'') ''Boulevard Saint-Michel''.Gifford (1988) 53. In 1904 the [[w:Boulevard Saint-Michel|Boulevard Saint-Michel]], a street on the [[w:Rive Gauche (Paris)|Left Bank]] of the Seine in Paris, was the café centre of the city's student and bohemian life. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/040|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/042|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=45]]
==Annotations== '''''Lui, c'est moi'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''I am he''.Gifford (1988) 53.
Thornton (1968) 51-52. Stephen's statement is a parody of the oft-quoted remark attributed to [[w:Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV of France]]: ''L'état, c'est moi'' (''I am the state''). '''''Encore deux minutes''. Look clock. Must get. ''Fermé'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Still two minutes to go ... Closed''.Gifford (1988) 53. Stephen is recalling an incident when he tried to cash a money order from his mother at a French post-office. When the door was closed in his face, he pleaded with the usher in broken French and English: ''There are still two minutes to go [before closing time]. Look [at the] clock. [I] must get [this money order cashed].'' To which the usher replied: ''[We're] closed''. '''''Euge! Euge!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Well done! Well done!''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 54}}
{{cite book |last = Thornton |first = Weldon |title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = The University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 52}} In the Latin Vulgate translation of the Bible, this interjection is always used ironically by a mocker, as is clearly intended here. English versions usually translate the original Hebrew as ''Aha'' or ''Ah'': :'''Ezekiel 25:3'''{{spaces|3}}''et dices filiis Ammon audite verbum Domini Dei haec dicit Dominus Deus pro eo quod dixisti '''euge euge''' super sanctuarium meum quia pollutum est et super terram Israhel quoniam desolata est et super domum Iuda quoniam ducti sunt in captivitatem''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel%2025&version=VULGATE Bible Gateway] :'''Ezekiel 25:3'''{{spaces|3}}''And say unto the Ammonites, Hear the word of the Lord GOD; Thus saith the Lord GOD; Because thou saidst, '''Aha''', against my sanctuary, when it was profaned; and against the land of Israel, when it was desolate; and against the house of Judah, when they went into captivity;''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel%2025&version=KJV Bible Gateway] The original Hebrew word is ''heach''.[http://concordances.org/hebrew/1889.htm Strong's Hebrew] '''''Comment'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''What?''Gifford (1988) 54. At [[w:Newhaven, East Sussex|Newhaven]] in England, on his way to Paris, Stephen pretended he was French and could not speak English in order to avoid having to pay a porter threepence to carry his valise. '''''Le Tutu'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') A ''[[wikt:tutu|tutu]]'' is a short ballet skirt.Gifford (1988) 54.
Thornton (1968) 52-53. ''Le Tutu'' was a humorous weekly magazine that first appeared in Paris on 25 March 1901. '''''Pantalon Blanc et Culotte Rouge'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''White Knickers and Red Panties''.Gifford (1988) 54.
Thornton (1968) 53. No such periodical is known, though the second half of the name recalls a geniune French magazine, ''La Vie en Culotte Rouge'' (''Life in Red Breeches'', or ''Among the Camp Followers'').[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb32888964b/date ''La Vie en Culotte Rouge''.] ''Culotte rouge'' is also French slang for a ''camp follower''. It has been suggested that Joyce concocted the title so as to strengthen the link between Stephen and Bloom, for whom women's undergarments are a fetish. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/070|070.33 - 071.37]], and of course ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nausicaa/331|Nausicaa]]''. '''Paris rawly waking, crude sunlight on her lemon streets. Moist pith of farls of bread, the froggreen wormwood, her matin incense, court the air. Belluomo rises from the bed of his wife's lover's wife, the kerchiefed housewife is astir, a saucer of acetic acid in her hand.'''{{spaces|5}}For this description of early morning in Paris, Joyce drew heavily upon his unpublished prose poem ''[[w:Giacomo Joyce|Giacomo Joyce]]'', where it is [[w:Trieste|Trieste]] that is being described: {{quote|''Trieste is waking rawly: raw sunlight over its huddled browntiled roofs, testudoform; a multitude of prostrate bugs awwait a national deliverance. Belluomo rises from the bed of his wife's lover's wife: the busy housewife is astir, sloe-eyed, a saucer of acetic acid in her hand.....''}} '''Belluomo'''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Handsome man''.Gifford (1988) 54. The Italian makes sense in the context of Trieste (see above). '''''chaussons'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''turnovers''.Gifford (1988) 54. A ''chausson'' is a [[wikt:turnover|turnover]] made, usually, with puff pastry and a fruit filling. ''Chaussons aux pommes'' are [[wikt:apple turnover|apple turnovers]]. '''''pus'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''pus''.Gifford (1988) 54. ''[[wikt:pus|Pus]]'' is a viscous yellowish liquid associated with bacterial infections (e.g. pimples). Stephen is referring to the yellow custard in a ''flan bréton''. '''''flan bréton'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''custard tart''.Gifford (1988) 54. In French ''[[wikt:flan|flan]]'' denotes a baked custard tart. The variety of custard tart associated with [[w:Brittany|Brittany]] is called a ''[[w:Far Breton|Far Breton]]''. But Stephen's reference to the yellow pus of the custard suggests that he has some sort of custard pastry in mind in which the custard is not set, such as a ''[[w:Mille-feuille|mille-feuille]]''. ''Breton'', without the acute accent on the ''e'', is the correct spelling. In the ''[[w:The Little Review|The Little Review]]'', which published an early draft of this episode in 1918, the word was spelt ''brêton''.[http://dl.lib.brown.edu/repository2/repoman.php?verb=render&id=1298917764984376&view=pageturner&pageno=39 ''The Little Review'' 5:1:37.] '''conquistadores'''{{spaces|5}}(''French Slang'') ''lady-killers''.Gifford (1988) 54. ''[[w:Conquistador|Conquistadores]]'' is a Spanish word for the soldiers, explorers and adventurers who conquered and colonized the territories that created the Spanish Empire in the 15th-17th cunturies; but the term is also used in several European languages to describe a [[wikt:lothario|lothario]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/041|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/043|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=46]]
==Annotations== '''''Un demi sétier'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French Slang'') ''A small black coffee''.Gifford (1988) 55. The usual French term for a small black coffee is ''[[wikt:demitasse|demitasse]]''. A ''sétier'' is an obsolete unit of capacity and volume. It was used before the French Revolution to express the capacity of dry substances, such as seeds and grains, and the volume of liquids. Its value varied from place to place, but the Parisian dry ''sétier'' was equal to 151.680 litres.{{cite book |title=Encyclopaedia of Scientific Units, Weights and Measures |last=Cardarelli |first=François |year=2003 |publisher=Springer |location=London |isbn=1-85233-682-X |page=582 |url=http://books.google.ie/books?id=6KCx8Ww75VkC}} The liquid ''sétier'' was equivalent to about 9 litres, or to 284 millilitres, depending on the source consulted.[http://books.google.ie/books?id=MX1FAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA505#v=onepage&q&f=false A. Boyer, ''Dictionnaire Royal'' 505, ''s.v.'' '''Poisson'''.]
[http://bosworth.ff.cuni.cz/page/b0866 Joseph Bosworth ''An Anglo-Saxon Dictionary'' 866, ''s.v.'' '''sester'''.] The latter would make a ''demi-sétier'' equal to about 142 ml, which is appropriate for a small cup of coffee. '''''Il est Irlandais. Hollandais? Non fromage. Deux Irlandais, nous, Irlande, vous savez? Ah oui!.'' she thought you wanted a cheese ''hollandais'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''He's Irish. Dutch? Not cheese. Two Irishmen, we, Ireland, you understand? Oh yes! She thought you wanted a Dutch cheese.''Gifford (1988) 55. Stephen recalls a conversation between Kevin Egan and a waitress in a Parisian restaurant. '''''slainte !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') ''sláinte !'' is the correct spelling. '''''sláinte !'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''health!'' A traditional Irish [[wikt:sláinte|toast]]. '''''Vieille ogresse with the dents jaunes'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Old ogress with the yellow teeth''.Gifford (1988) 55.
Thornton (1968) 54. The words occur in [[w:Édouard Drumont|Édouard Drumont's]] ''Le Testament d'un antisémite'' (''The Last Will and Testament of an Antisemite''): {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Le Testament d'un antisémite'''''[http://www.jjon.org/joyce-s-allusions/vieille-ogresse James Joyce Online Notes.]
[http://www.archive.org/stream/letestamentduna01drumgoog#page/n185/mode/1up Édouard Drumont, ''Le Testament d'un antisémite'' 162.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Cela rappelle la réponse de Frédérick Lemaître à la reine Victoria. Frédérick avait été jouer à Londres ''Le Chiffonnier de Paris''; la reine l'avait fait venir dans sa loge, et la vieille ogresse aux dents jaunes avait feint l'attendrissement.'' '' - Comment, vous avez de pareilles misères à Paris?'' '' - Madame, répondit Frédérick avec sa voix tonnante et son grand geste, ce sont nos Irlandais...'' | ''This recalls the response of [[w:Frédérick Lemaître|Frédérick Lemaître]] to Queen Victoria. Frédérick had been playing in London ''The Rag-Picker of Paris''; the queen had summoned him to her box, and the old ogress with the yellow teeth had feigned tenderness.'' '' - How can there be such misery in Paris?'' '' - Madam, Frédérick replied with a booming voice and grand gesture, these are our Irish...'' |} According to Gifford, in folklore cannibalism was believed to turn the teeth yellow. '''''La Patrie'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''The Fatherland''.Gifford (1988) 55.
Thornton (1968) 54. ''[[w:fr:La Patrie (Paris)|La Patrie]]'' was a French political journal. Founded in 1841 and published daily, it was politically conservative. '''froeken'''{{spaces|5}}(''Swedish'') ''young unmarried woman''.Gifford (1988) 55. The Swedish spelling is ''[[wikt:fröken|fröken]]''. '''''bonne à tout faire'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''maid of all work''.Gifford (1988) 55. '''''Moi faire'', she said. ''Tous les messieurs'' not this ''Monsieur'' I said.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') Gabler emends this thus:Gabler (1986) 36. :''Moi faire'', she said, ''tous les messieurs''. Not this ''monsieur'', I said. In ''[[w:The Little Review|The Little Review]]'', which published an earlier draft of this chapter in 1918, the passage is printed thus:[http://dl.lib.brown.edu/repository2/repoman.php?verb=render&id=1298917764984376&view=pageturner&pageno=39 ''The Little Review'', Volume 5, No. 1, Page 39.] :''Moi faire'', she said. ''Tous les messieurs.'' Most licentious custom. '''''Moi faire'', she said. ''Tous les messieurs.'' Not this ''monsieur'', I said'''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''I do'', she said. ''All the gentlemen.'' ''Not this gentleman'', I said.Gifford (1988) 56. Stephen recalls another remark made to him by Kevin Egan in Paris. '''rue de la Goutte-d'Or'''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Street of the Drop of Gold''.Gifford (1988) 57. The [[w:Goutte d'Or:|Goutte d'Or:]] is a suburb of Paris in the [[w:18th arrondissement of Paris|18th arrondissement]], named for the ancient vineyards that once produced a golden white wine here. The ''[[w:fr:Rue de la Goutte d'Or|Rue de la Goutte d'Or]]'' runs from the ''Rue Polonceau'' to 22 ''Boulevard Barbès''. Gabler italicizes this phrase.Gabler (1986) 36. '''rue Gît-le-Cœur'''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') A [[w:fr:Rue Gît-le-Cœur|street]] in the [[w:6th arrondissement of Paris|6th arrondissement]] of Paris.Gifford (1988) 57. It is a narrow street, close to the Left Bank of the Seine. It runs roughly paralel to the [[w:boulevard Saint-michel|boulevard Saint-michel]]. The name, which translates literally as ''Lies-the-Heart Street'', is a corruption of ''Rue Gilles le Queux'' (''Gilles the Cook Street''). Gabler italicizes the name.Gabler (1986) 36. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/042|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/044|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=47]]
==Annotations== '''''Mon fils'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''My son''.Gifford (1988) 57. '''''Un coche ensablé'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''A coach stuck in the sand''.Gifford (1988) 58. Stephen adapts the phrase from an essay by Louis Veuillot, ''Le Vrai poète Parisien'' (''The True Parisian Poet''), in his collection ''Les Odeurs de Paris'' (''The Smells of Paris'').[http://archive.org/stream/lesodeursdeparis00veuiuoft#page/234/mode/2up Louis Veuillot, ''Les Odeurs de Paris'' 235] Veuillot is criticizing Gautier's ''Étude'' (''Study''), his funeral oration for the German poet [[w:Heinrich Heine|Heinrich Heine]].[http://archive.org/stream/portraitsetsouv00gautgoog#page/n114/mode/2up Théophile Gautier, ''Portraits et souvenirs littéraires'' 105-128.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/043|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/045|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=48]]
==Annotations== '''''Terribilia meditans'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Meditating on terrifying things.''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 59}} This sounds like a quotation or allusion, but no source has been found. '''''Natürlich'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''Naturally, Normal''.Gifford (1988) 60. Why does Stephen use German here? ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/044|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/046|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=49]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid #bfb; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=50]]
==Annotations== '''the red Egyptians'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Gypsy|Gypsies]].Gifford (1988) 61.
Thornton (1968) 60-61. In Ireland, however, ''Gypsies'' usually refers to members of the [[w:Irish Travellers|Travelling Community]], who are ethnically Irish. In this passage Stephen is relying for his quotations and information on [[w:Richard Head|Richard Head's]] ''[[w:Slang dictionary|The Canting Academy]]'' of 1673. Head describes the Gypsies thus: {{quote|The principal Professors of this Gibberish or Canting, I find, are a sort of People which are vulgarly called ''Gypsies''; and they do endeavour to perswade the ignorant, that they were extracted from the ''Egyptians'' ... they artificially discolour their faces, and with this tawny hew and tatterdemallion habit, they rove up and down the Country, and with the pretension of wonderful prediction, delude a many of the younger and less intelligent people.Richard Head, ''The Canting Academy'', London (1673), page 2.}} '''blued feet'''{{spaces|5}}Stephen is probably referring to the discoloration of the feet which occurs when the traditional blue dye [[w:Indigo dye|indigo]] is worked into fabrics by treading barefoot in the vats. In ancient Egypt the preparation of the indigo for the vats also involved treading.[http://books.google.ie/books?id=ua83AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA136&lpg=PA136#v=onepage&q&f=false Robert James Forbes, ''Studies in Ancient Technology'' 136.] '''ruffian'''{{spaces|5}}In standard English ''ruffian'' is a pejorative term for a lawless thug. In [[w:Thieves' cant|thieves' cant]], ''ruffin'' or ''ruffian'' refers specifically to the Devil. Stephen may have confused the two. In [[w:Richard Head|Richard Head's]] ''[[w:Slang dictionary|The Canting Academy]]'', male gypsies are usually called ''rogues'' or ''coves''. '''strolling mort'''{{spaces|5}}(''Thieves' Cant'') ''wandering wench''. In [[w:Richard Head|Richard Head's]] ''[[w:Slang dictionary|The Canting Academy]]'', ''Strowling Morts'' are described thus: {{quote|Strowling-Morts are such as pretend to be Widdows, travelling about from County to County, making laces upon [st]aves, as Beggars tape, or the like; they are subtil Queans, hard-hearted, light-fingered, hypocritical and dissembling, and very dangerous to meet, if any ''Ruffler'' or ''Rogue'' be in their company.Richard Head, ''The Canting Academy'', London (1673), page 86.}} '''bing awast, to Romeville'''{{spaces|5}}(''Thieves' Cant'') ''Go away, to London''.Gifford (1988) 61.
Thornton (1968) 61. Stephen is quoting the first line of the seventh and final stanza of the canting song, ''The Rogue's Delight in Praise of his Strolling Mort'', which Richard Head includes in ''The Canting Academy''. ''Rome'' means ''rum'', i.e. ''excellent''; ''Romeville'' is the [[w:Thieves' cant|cant]] term for London. See below. '''Buss'''{{spaces|5}}(''archaic'') ''Kiss''. ''[[wikt:buss|Buss]]'' is archaic English. It is not, and never has been, [[w:Thieves' cant|cant]]. '''wap in rogue's rum lingo'''{{spaces|5}}(''Thieves' cant'') ''kiss, in the excellent language of the Gypsies''.Gifford (1988) 61. Stephen translates the Shakespearean term ''buss'' into [[w:Thieves' cant|cant]]. On the term ''lingo'', Eric Partridge writes: {{quote|'''lingo''' was in [the 18th century], and occ[asionally] later, a synonym of ''the slang, the flash ''(''language''); just - only just - possibly it was, for a decade, c[ant] in this specific sense.{{cite book |title=Dictionary of the Underworld |last=Partridge |first=Eric |year=1995 |publisher=Wordsworth Editions Ltd |location=Ware |isbn=1-85326-361-3 |page=410}}}} '''O, my dimber wapping dell'''{{spaces|5}}(''Thieves' Cant'') ''O, my pretty loving wench''.Gifford (1988) 61.
Thornton (1968) 61. Stephen is quoting the second line of the seventh and final stanza of the canting song, ''The Rogue's Delight in Praise of his Strolling Mort'', which Richard Head includes in ''The Canting Academy''. ''To wap'' means ''to copulate''. See below. '''''White thy fambles ... clip and kiss'''''{{spaces|5}} (''Thieves' Cant'') This is the second stanza of the canting song, ''The Rogue's Delight in Praise of his Strolling Mort'', which Richard Head includes in ''The Canting Academy'':Richard Head, ''The Canting Academy'', London (1673), pp. 19-20. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''The Rogue's Delight in Praise of his Strolling Mort''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Doxy oh! Thy Glaziers shine'' ''As Glymmar by the Salomon,'' ''No Gentry Mort hath prats like thine'' ''No Cove e're wap'd with such a one.'' ''White thy fambles, red thy gan,'' ''And thy quarrons dainty is,'' ''Couch a hogshead with me than,'' ''In the Darkmans clip and kiss.'' ''What though I no Togeman wear,'' ''Nor Commission, Mish, or slate,'' ''Store of strummel wee'l have here.'' ''And i'th' Skipper lib in state.'' ''Wapping thou I know dost love,'' ''Else the Ruffin cly thee Mort,'' ''From thy stampers then remove'' ''Thy Drawers and let's prig in sport.'' ''When the Lightmans up do's call'' ''Margery Prater from her nest,'' ''And her Cackling cheats with all'' ''In a Boozing-Ken wee'l feast.'' ''There if Lour we want I'l mill'' ''A Gage or nip for thee a bung,'' ''Rum booz thou shalt booz thy fill'' ''And crash a Grunting cheat that's young.'' ''Bing awast to Rome-vile then'' ''O my dimber wapping Dell,'' ''Wee'l heave a booth and dock agen'' ''Then trining scape and all is well.'' | ''Wench oh! Thy eyes shine'' ''As fire by the Mass''By the Mass'', I believe, is an oath, referring to the Catholic Mass. Hence: ''Your eyes are as bright as fire, by God!'' ''No gentlewoman has thighs like thine'' ''No fellow ever made love with such a one.'' ''White thy hands, red thy mouth,'' ''And thy body dainty is,'' ''Lie down with me then,'' ''In the night embrace and kiss.'' ''What though I no cloak wear,'' ''Nor shirt, chemise, or sheet,'' ''Plenty of straw we'll have here.'' ''And in the barn sleep in state.'' ''Copulating thou I know dost love,'' ''Else the Devil seize thee, wench,'' ''From thy feet then remove'' ''Thy stockings and let's ride in sport.'' ''When the Sun rises and does call'' ''The hen from her nest,'' ''And her chickens withal'' ''In a tippling-house we'll feast.'' ''There if money we want I'll steal'' ''A pot or nab for thee a purse,'' ''Excellent liquor thou shalt drink thy fill'' ''And crunch a pig that's young.'' ''Go away to London then'' ''O my pretty loving wench,'' ''We'll rob a house and fuck again'' ''Then hanging escape and all is well.'' |} '''''frate porcospino'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Brother Porcupine''.Gifford (1988) 61.
Thornton (1968) 61. Stephen is probably referring to Aquinas's habit of surrounding his assertions with a defensive ring of arguments, which makes it as difficult to attack him as it is to attack a [[wikt:porcospino|porcupine or hedgehog]]. '''''oinopa ponton'', a winedark sea'''{{spaces|5}}See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/005|005.13]]. '''''Omnis caro ad te veniet'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''All flesh shall come unto thee.''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 62}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 62}} This quotation, adapted from Psalms 65:1-2 (Vulgate 64:1-2),[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalmi+64&version=VULGATE Bible Gateway] occurs in the [[w:Introit|Introit]] of the [[w:Requiem|Mass for the Dead]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/046|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/048|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=51]]
==Annotations== '''''piuttosto'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''rather''.Gifford (1988) 63. '''''Et vidit Deus. Et erant valde bona.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''And God saw [every thing that he had made], and, behold, it was very good.'' Adapted from Genesis 1:31.[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis%201&version=VULGATE Bible Gateway]
{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 63}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 63}} ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/047|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/049|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=52]]
==Annotations== '''''nebeneinander'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''side by side''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/037|037.13]]. '''tripudium'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') In ancient Rome, the ''[[wikt:tripudium|tripudium]]'' was a solemn ceremonial dance.Gifford (1988) 63. The word denotes a triple stroke, in which the Earth is stamped three times with the foot.[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/searchresults?q=tripudium ''Tripudium'']. Joyce does not italicize the word, treating it as an English borrowing. '''''Tiens, quel petit pied!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''My, what a small foot!''Gifford (1988) 64. '''''diebus ac noctibus iniurias patiens ingemiscit.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''days and nights it [Creation] sighs patiently over injustices.''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 64}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |page = 65}} A quotation from the ''Commentary on the Epistle of Blessed Paul to the Romans'', long attributed to [[w:Ambrose|Saint Ambrose]] but now ascribed to a contemporary of his styled [[w:Ambrosiaster|Ambrosiaster]]. The comment is to Romans 8:22, ''For we know that the whole creation groaneth and travaileth in pain together until now'',[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Romans%208&version=KJV Bible Gateway]
[http://www.documentacatholicaomnia.eu/04z/z_0339-0397__Ambrosius__In_Epistolam_Beati_Pauli_Ad_Romanos__MLT.pdf.html ''In Epistolam Beati Pauli Ad Romanos] Paul's '''συστεναζει''' (''sustenazei'') means both ''sighs together'' and ''groans together''. [[w:Jerome|Saint Jerome's]] Latin translation ''ingemiscit'' also carries both meanings, ''sighs'' and ''groans''.[http://concordances.org/greek/4959.htm Strong's Greek.] When read in context, however, Paul's point is that ''all of creation has been groaning, as though in the pangs of childbirth, right up to the present time.'' Thornton suggests that Joyce probably came across the comment "in some choir manual or [[wikt:sodality manual|sodality manual]]." [[w:Marsh's Library|Marsh's Library]], however, has a copy of the complete works of St Ambrose (Basle, 1506), which includes the commentary on ''Romans''.[http://www.marshlibrary.ie/catalogue?key1=a&uval1=Ambrose;+St.;+Bishop+of+Milan;+c.+340-97+&op2=&key2=&uval2=&coll=3&adv=n ''Omnia opera; Ambrosius episcopi Mediolanensis'', F. Conradus Leontorius (editor), Basle (1506).]
[http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/bsb00008239/images/bsb00008239_00411.jpg ''In Epistolam Ad Romanos''.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/048|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/050|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=53]]
==Annotations== '''''Prix de Paris'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') The ''[[w:Grand Prix de Paris|Grand Prix de Paris]]'' (''Great Prize of Paris'') was the most important event in French horse racing.Gifford (1988) 65.
Thornton (1968) 66. The mention of ''Old Father Ocean'' has reminded Stephen, perhaps, of ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/038|the steeds of Mananaan]]'' See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Nestor/032|032.17]]. Stephen is probably also punning on the story of the [[w:Judgement of Paris|Judgement of Paris]], in which the Prince of Troy awarded the ''[[w:Apple of Discord|Apple of Discord]]'' to [[w:Aphrodite|Aphrodite]], precipitating the [[w:Trojan War|Trojan War]]. Paris's prize for choosing Aphrodite was Helen of Troy. '''beware of imitations'''{{spaces|5}}In a [[w:Palinode|palinode]] attributed to the Greek poet [[w:Stesichorus|Stesichorus]], the Trojan War was fought over a phantom Helen, while the real Helen was living in Egypt under the protection of King Proteus.[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Dio_Chrysostom/Discourses/11*.html Dio Chrysostom, ''Discourses'' 11:40 ff.] The historian [[w:Herodotus|Herodotus]] recounts a similar tradition in his ''[[w:Histories (Herodotus)|Histories]]''.[http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/2707/pg2707.txt Herodotus, ''Histories'' 2:112.] The Greek playwright [[w:Euripides|Euripides]] also draws upon this tradition for his drama ''[[w:Helen (play)|Helen]]'', in which Helen is reunited with her husband [[w:Menelaus|Menelaus]] when he is marooned in Egypt on his way home from Troy.[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Eur.+Hel.+1 Euripides, ''Helen''.] This latter event, of course, is the Homeric background Joyce drew upon when he wrote the Proteus episode of ''Ulysses''. '''''Lucifer, dico, qui nescit occasum'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''The Morning Star, I say, who knows no setting.''{{cite book |last1 = Gifford |first1 = Don |last2 = Seidman |first2 = Robert J. |title = Ulysses Annotated |publisher = University of California Press |year = 1988 |page = 65}}
{{cite book |last1 = Thornton|first1 = Weldon|title = Allusions in Ulysses |publisher = University of North Carolina Press |year = 1968 |pages = 66-67}} Stephen's adapts this quotation from the [[w:Easter Vigil|Easter Vigil]], the Catholic service for [[w:Holy saturday|Holy saturday]]. The [[w:Exsultet|Exultet]] or Easter Proclamation, sung by the [[w:deacon|deacon]] before the [[w:Paschal Candle|Paschal Candle]], concludes with the words: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Exultet''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''May the early Morning Star find his flames [still burning]:'' ''He, I say, the Morning Star, who knows no setting.'' ''Christ your Son,'' ''Who, returned from the dead, has shed his peaceful light on the human race,'' ''And who lives and reigns for ever and ever.'' ''Amen'' | ''Flammas eius lúcifer matutínus invéniat:'' ''ille, inquam, Lúcifer, qui nescit occásum.'' ''Christus Fílius tuus,'' ''qui, regréssus ab ínferis, humáno géneri serénus illúxit,'' ''et vivit et regnat in sæcula sæculórum.'' ''Amen.'' |} ''Lucifer'' means ''the bringer of light'' and was applied to the [[w:Morning Star|Morning Star]] by the ancient Romans. In the ''Exultet'' it refers to the risen Christ. But Lucifer is also a name for [[w:Satan|Satan]], so Stephen's phrase can also be translated: ''Lucifer, I say, who knows no fall.'' See '''Isaiah 14:12:''' ''How art thou fallen from heaven, O Lucifer,[http://concordances.org/hebrew/1966.htm Strong's Hebrew.] son of the morning! how art thou cut down to the ground, which didst weaken the nations!''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2014&version=KJV Bible Gateway] See '''Luke 10:18:''' ''I beheld Satan as lightning fall from Heaven.''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Luke%2010&version=KJV Bible Gateway] '''''Già'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Indeed''.Gifford (1988) 66. According to Gifford, Stephen is using the word to express impatience; he feels that he has spent enough time wandering across Sanymount Strand and is urging himself to get a move on. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Proteus/049|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Calypso/051|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=64]]
==Annotations== '''''Là ci darem'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''There we shall join [hands]''.Gifford (1988) 77.
Thornton (1968) 73. These are the opening words of the [[w:Duettino|duettino]] ''Là ci darem la mano'', Act I, Number 7 of [[w:Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart's]] comic opera ''[[w:Don Giovanni|Don Giovanni]]'', in which the Don, a sexual predator, begins his seduction of the peasant Masetto's young bride Zerlina. The opera occupies Bloom's mind for the rest of the day on account of the similarity between his and Masetto's predicaments:[[s:it:Don Giovanni/Atto Primo/Scena nona|''Don Giovanni''' Act 1, Scene 9.]] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Là ci darem la mano''''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ;Don Giovanni :Là ci darem la mano, :Là mi dirai di sì. :Vedi, non è lontano; :Partiam, ben mio, da qui. ;Zerlina :(Vorrei e non vorrei, :Mi trema un poco il cor. :Felice, è ver, sarei, :Ma può burlarmi ancor.) ;Don Giovanni :Vieni, mio bel diletto! ;Zerlina :(Mi fa pietà Masetto.) ;Don Giovanni :Io cangierò tua sorte. ;Zerlina :Presto ... non son più forte. ;Don Giovanni :Andiam! ;Zerlina :Andiam! ;A due :Andiam, andiam, mio bene. :a ristorar le pene :D’un innocente amor.'' | ;Don Giovanni :There we shall join hands, :There you shall say "Yes" to me. :See, it's not far; :Let's leave here, my dear. ;Zerlina :(I would like to, and I wouldn't like to, :My heart is aflutter a little. :It's true, I would be happy, :But he can still make a fool of me.) ;Don Giovanni :Come, my pretty beloved! ;Zerlina :(I feel sorry for Masetto.) ;Don Giovanni :I will change your destiny. ;Zerlina :Quickly ... I am no longer strong. ;Don Giovanni :Let's go! ;Zerlina :Let us go! ;Both :Let us go, let us go, my darling, :To cure the pains :Of an innocent love.'' |} '''''Voglio e non vorrei'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''I want to but I wouldn't like to''.Gifford (1988) 77.
Thornton (1968) 73 Bloom has misremembered Zerlina's line. He will correct it in ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Hades/090|Hades]]'', but he continually makes the same mistake throughout the day. It has been suggested that Bloom is thinking of a pair of lines spoken by Don Giovanni's servant Leporello in the opening scene: ''Voglio far il gentiluomo/E non voglio più servir'' (''I want to be a gentleman/And I no longer wish to serve'').[[s:it:Don Giovanni/Atto Primo/Scena_prima|''Don Giovanni''' Act 1, Scene 1.]] In ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/417|Circe]]'', two pages before repeating the mistake, Bloom addresses Molly with the words ''At your service''. Zerlina's ''Vorrei e non vorrei'' (''I would like to and I wouldn't like to'') might be more loosely translated as: ''I would like to, but I shouldn't'', or ''Should I or shouldn't I?''. '''Wonder if she pronounces that right : ''voglio'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') The word ''voglio'' (''I want to'') is pronounced [ˈvɔʎo] in [[W:International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]], (vOLo in [[w:Extended Speech Assessment Methods Phonetic Alphabet|X-SAMPA]], ''vawl-yo'' phonetically). Of course, this is all irrelevant to Molly, who won't be called upon to sing this word. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Calypso/060|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Calypso/062|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Abraxas Malfoy

revision.comment: /* Analysis */ why Abraxas was brought in at all
revision.text:
{{Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Character| name=Abraxas Malfoy| gender=Male| hair=Unknown| eyes=Unknown| family=Son [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Lucius Malfoy|Lucius Malfoy]], grandson [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Draco Malfoy|Draco]]| loyalty=unknown, probably Pureblood }}
== Overview ==
'''''Abraxas Malfoy''''' was grandfather to [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Draco Malfoy|Draco]], and father to [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Lucius Malfoy|Lucius Malfoy]]. He knew [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Horace Slughorn|Horace Slughorn]] and died of Dragon Pox, presumably at an old age.
== Role in the Books ==
{{Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Beginner Spoiler}}
=== [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Books/Half-Blood Prince|Half-Blood Prince]] ===
In their first [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Magic/Potions|Potions]] class, [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Draco Malfoy|Draco]] asks [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Horace Slughorn|Slughorn]] if he remembers his grandfather. Slughorn replies that he does and is sorry to hear of his death but it was not unexpected, "Dragon Pox, at his age" before turning away.
Professor Slughorn mentions Draco's grandfather again in the Slug Club Christmas party.
== Strengths ==
== Weaknesses ==
== Relationships with Other Characters ==
Apparently distant friends with Horace Slughorn, who is probably about his age; they may have attended Hogwarts at the same time.
== Analysis ==
We know that Professor Slughorn is more than a bit of a social climber, and that he seems to cut off those people who he feels don't offer him an "in" into the higher-flying parts of society. The fact that he acknowledges knowing Abraxas Malfoy would indicate that there was some fame or accomplishment in Abraxas' past to attract Slughorn's attention. We never find out, though, exactly what that accomplishment is.
Abraxas is brought into the story, as far as we can see, only to cast a light on Slughorn and some specifics of his social climbing. In [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Books/Half-Blood Prince/Chapter 7|an earlier chapter]], we see that Slughorn is willing to cultivate [[Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Characters/Marcus Belby|Marcus Belby]] as long as he has hopes of making a connection with Belby's still living famous uncle. As Abraxas is no longer alive and does not represent a useful connection. Slughorn is not particularly interested in those who had connections to him. We suspect that this particular shallowness in Slughorn's character is one of the things that Harry dislikes, and one of the reasons Harry avoids the Slug Club.
== Questions == {{Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Questions}}
== Greater Picture ==
{{Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter/Intermediate Spoiler}}
[[Category:Muggles' Guide to Harry Potter]]

page.title: How to Read Young Adult Literature Like a Young Adult Writer/Hunger Games

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/82.112.83.242|82.112.83.242]] ([[User talk:82.112.83.242|talk]]) to last version by Glaisher
revision.text:
== The Hunger Games ==
The Hunger Games is a young adult science fiction novel by Suzanne Colins. There are three novels in the series: The Hunger Games, Catching Fire and Mockingjay.
It is set in a dystopian, post-apocalyptic future in a country called Panem in the remains of the USA, separated into fourteen administrative regions. There are thirteen districts (District 1, District 2, District 3 etc.) and the capital, Capitol. Each district specializes in something, e.g. mining, fishing, electronics, and supplies this to the Capitol. Seventy four years before The Hunger Games the districts rebelled against the Capitol, but were beaten, all apart from District 13 which was supposedly destroyed, and now have to pay the price of their rebellion. Every child in each district is entered into "the reaping". Their names are submitted and two are drawn out at random, one boy and one girl, and they will have to compete in The Hunger Games. This is a TV program to be watched in the Capitol, each of the twenty four contestants is placed into an unknown arena and have to kill each other. Only one will survive the games, the rest of them are all killed, and will then live a life of luxury in their district, although afterwards most turn to drugs. The winners have to mentor the next participants.
{{BookCat}}
