[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=135]]
==Annotations== ==References== {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/131|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/133|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=136]]
==Annotations== '''''la tua pace ... si tace'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') Stephen recalls the closing words of lines 92 and 94 and all of line 96 in Canto 5 of [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]'':Gifford (1988) 143.
Thornton (1968) 120-121. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Inferno'' 5:88-96''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''"O animal grazïoso e benigno'' ''che visitando vai per l’aere perso'' ''noi che tignemmo il mondo di sanguigno,'' ''se fosse amico il re dell’universo,'' ''noi pregheremmo lui de la tua pace,'' ''poi c’hai pietà del nostro mal perverso.'' ''Di quel che udire e che parlar vi piace,'' ''noi udiremo e parleremo a vui,'' ''mentre che ’l vento, come fa, ci tace.'' | ''"O creature gracious and benign,'' ''Who goest through the murky air, visiting'' ''Us, who stained the world with blood,'' ''If the king of the universe were a friend,'' ''We would pray to him for your peace,'' ''Since thou hast pity on our evil plight.'' ''Of that which it pleases thee to hear and speak'' ''We shall hear and speak to thee,'' ''Whilst the wind, as it is, is silent.'' |} The speakers are the adulterers [[w:Paolo Malatesta|Paolo Malatesta]] and [[w:Francesca da Rimini|Francesca da Rimini]]. Joyce's ''. . . .mentreche'' has been emended to ''Mentre che'' in Gabler's corrected text.Gabler (1984) 114. '''He saw them three by three ... underdarkneath the night'''{{spaces|5}}Following the allusion to Dante's ''Inferno'', Stephen now conflates two episodes from the remaining parts of the ''[[w:Divine Comedy|Divine Comedy]]'': the Divine Pageant (or Mystic Procession) in the 29th canto of the ''[[w:Purgatorio|Purgatorio]]'', and the vision of the [[w:Mary (mother of Jesus)|Virgin Mary]] in the 31st canto of the ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]''.Gifford (1988) 143.
Thornton (1968) 121. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Purgatorio'' 29:121-135''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Tre donne in giro da la destra rota'' ''venian danzando; l'una tanto rossa'' ''ch'a pena fora dentro al foco nota;'' ''l'altr'era come se le carni e l'ossa'' ''fossero state di smeraldo fatte;'' ''la terza parea neve teste' mossa;'' ''e or parean da la bianca tratte,'' ''or da la rossa; e dal canto di questa'' ''l'altre toglien l'andare e tarde e ratte.'' ''Da la sinistra quattro facean festa,'' ''in porpore vestite, dietro al modo'' ''d'una di lor ch'avea tre occhi in testa.'' ''Appresso tutto il pertrattato nodo'' ''vidi due vecchi in abito dispari,'' ''ma pari in atto e onesto e sodo.'' | ''Three ladies in a ring at the right wheel'' ''came dancing; one so red'' ''that scarcely would she have been noticed in the fire;'' ''the next was as though her flesh and bones'' ''had been made of emerald;'' ''the third seemed snow newly fallen;'' ''and now they seemed to be led by the white,'' ''now by the red; and from the song of this one'' ''the others took their pace, both slow and fast.'' ''On the left four made festival,'' ''in purple clothed, after the manner'' ''of one of them, who had three eyes in her head.'' ''Behind the whole of the aforementioned knot'' ''I saw two old men in disparate habits,'' ''but alike in their actions both honest and solid.'' |} {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Paradiso'' 31:124-142''' |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''E come quivi ove s’aspetta il temo'' ''che mal guidò Fetonte, più s’infiamma,'' ''e quinci e quindi il lume si fa scemo,'' ''così quella pacifica oriafiamma'' ''nel mezzo s’avvivava, e d’ogne parte'' ''per igual modo allentava la fiamma;'' ''e a quel mezzo, con le penne sparte,'' ''vid’ io più di mille angeli festanti,'' ''ciascun distinto di fulgore e d’arte.'' ''Vidi a lor giochi quivi e a lor canti'' ''ridere una bellezza, che letizia'' ''era ne li occhi a tutti li altri santi;'' ''e s’io avessi in dir tanta divizia'' ''quanta ad imaginar, non ardirei'' ''lo minimo tentar di sua delizia.'' ''Bernardo, come vide li occhi miei'' ''nel caldo suo calor fissi e attenti,'' ''li suoi con tanto affetto volse a lei,'' ''che ’ miei di rimirar fé più ardenti.'' | ''And as the place where one awaits the shaft'' ''that [[w:Phaëton|Phaëton]] ill guided is most inflamed,'' ''while on this side and on that the light abates,'' ''so that peaceful Oriflamme'' ''was rekindled in the middle, while on each side'' ''in equal measure the flame weakened;'' ''and at that middle, with their wings displayed,'' ''I saw more than a thousand jubilant angels,'' ''each one distinct in splendour and in skill.'' ''I saw, at their games there and at their songs'' ''smiling, a beautiful one, who joy'' ''was in the eyes of all the other saints;'' ''and if I had in speech as much abundance divizia'' ''as in imagination, I would not dare'' ''attempt the least of her delights.'' ''[[w:Bernard of Clairvaux|Bernard]], as soon as he saw my eyes'' ''on her warm heat fixed and attentive,'' ''his own with such affection he turned to her'' ''that he made mine more eager to regaze.'' |} '''He saw them three by three'''{{spaces|5}}[[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante]], who employed ''[[w:Terza rima|terza rima]]'' in his ''[[w:Divine Comedy|Divine Comedy]]''. '''three by three'''{{spaces|5}}This phrase does not occur in the passages Stephen conflates. GiffordGifford (1988) 143. mistranslates ''Purgatorio'' 29:110 ''tre e tre'' as ''three by three'', believing it refers to the three approaching ladies, but ''tre e tre'' means ''three and three'', and refers to the first three and final three of the seven bands in the Divine Pageant: twenty-four elders, representing the books of the [[w:Old Testament|Old Testament]]; the four [[w:Living creatures (Bible)|Living Creatures of the Apocalypse]], representing the four [[w:Gospel|Gospels]]; the three ladies, representing the three [[w:Theological virtues|Theological Virtues]], Faith, Hope and Charity; four dancers, representing the four [[w:Cardinal virtues|Cardinal Virtues]], Prudence, Justice, Temperance and Fortitude; two old men, representing the ''[[w:Acts of the Apostles|Acts of the Apostles]]'' and the [[w:Pauline epistles|Epistles of Saint Paul]]; four humble men, representing the [[w:General epistles|Epistles of Saints Peter, James, John and Jude]]; and one old man, representing the ''[[w:Book of Revelation|Book of Revelation]]''. Stephen, however, is still thinking of the ''[[w:terza rima|terza rima]]'' Dante employs in his ''Comedy'', in which the rhymes occur three by three. '''entwining'''{{spaces|5}}Stephen is thinking of the manner in which the rhymes are entwined in Dante's ''[[w:Terza rima|terza rima]]''. '''''per l'aere perso'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''through the murky air''. In his ''[[w:Convivio|Convivio]]'', Dante defines ''perse'' as ''a colour mingled of purple and of black, but the black predominates''.[http://archive.org/stream/convivioofdantea00dantiala#page/325/mode/1up Dante, ''Convivio'' 4:20.] See the quotation from Dante's ''Inferno'' 5:89 above. '''''quella pacifica oriafiamma'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''that peaceful Oriflamme''. See the quotation from [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]'' 31:127 above. The ''[[w:Oriflamme|Oriflamme]]'' was the battle standard of the kings of France. '''''di rimirar fè più ardenti'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''made ''[''my eyes'']'' more eager to regaze''. See the quotation from [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Paradiso (Dante)|Paradiso]]'' 31:142 above. These are the closing words of the canto. '''But I old men'''{{spaces|5}}Dante saw his rhymes three by three as colourful girls, but Stephen sees the rhymes he employed in the quatrain he wrote in ''Proteus'' as pairs of old men. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Aeolus/127|127.20-23]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 26%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/132|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/134|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=137]]
==Annotations== '''ITALIA, MAGISTRA ARTIUM'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Italy, Mistress of the Arts''.Gifford (1988) 146. There may be an allusion to the [[w:Master of Arts|Master of Arts]] or ''Magister Artium'', a postgraduate degree awarded by universities for excellence in the [[w:humanities|humanities]]. In the Middle Ages the arts in question were the [[w:Seven Liberal Arts|Seven Liberal Arts]], but new subjects were gradually added to the curriculum. '''''lex talionis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''law of talion''; ''law of retaliation in kind''. The [[wikt:lex talionis|lex talionis]] is the Latin form of the Mosaic principle of ''[[w:Eye for an eye|an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth]]'', in which the punishment inflicted upon a criminal is similar to the crime he committed.Gifford (1988) 146.
Thornton (1968) 123.
[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus%2021&version=KJV Exodus 21:23-25] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/133|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Aeolus/135|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=141]]
==Annotations== '''''Fuit Ilium!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Troy has been!''Gifford (1988) 150.
Thornton (1968) 126. The quotation is from [[w:Virgil|Virgil's]] epic poem the ''[[w:Aeneid|Aeneid]]'' 2:325: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Aeneid'' 2:325-326'''[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0054%3Abook%3D2%3Acard%3D318 ''Aeneid'']
[http://www.theoi.com/Text/VirgilAeneid2.html H. R. Fairclough's Translation] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''...: We Trojans are no more, Ilium is no more, nor the great''
''Glory of the Teucrians;'' | ''...: fuimus Troes, fuit Ilium et ingens''
''Gloria Teucrorum; |} ''[[w:Ilium|Ilium]]'' is a Latinized form of ''Ilion'' (Ἴλιον), another name for the legendary city of Troy, whence the title of Homer's ''Iliad''. The Trojans were sometimes known as ''Teucri'' (''Teucrians'') after [[w:King Teucer|Teucer]], ''earliest ancestor'' of the Trojans.[http://www.theoi.com/Text/VirgilAeneid3.html ''Aeneid'' 3:104 ff.] ==References== {{reflist}} {| style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

== Comment on presentation of Rule 110 ==
The information presented is dense. There is not enough explanatory English text. One would need to know a lot about CA in advance in order to make sense of the page? Михал Орела http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User:MihalOrela 14:05, 24 November 2011 (UTC)
== Garden of Eden regular expression correct? ==
The shortest sequence I can generate with the garden of eden regular expression 0*1(00*1+1(1+00)*010)*1(1+00)*011(0+1)* is 11011
11011 is not a garden of eden state as 1010011 is it's parent.
Also I cannot seem to generate 01010, which does appear to be a garden of eden state as stated, with the regular expression.
Perhaps I am reading the symbols wrong, I am interpreting them with the same meaning they have in POSIX regexes. even if I interpret the plus symbol as a union, I can get 11011 and not 01010. It just seems incorrect to me.
If no one can explain where this regex comes from someone should delete it. Also a citation would be nice, then we could actually verify these things from an authoritative source.
For all I know that could be a regex of garden of eden states for a different rule that got placed here by mistake.

== Predator-prey dynamics ==
Most of the material is classical mathematics. There are some diagrams at the bottom which are CA-related? The page would NOT ENCOURAGE the inquisitive visitor... One really needs to emphasize the CA up front rather than presenting the classical differential equations? Михал Орела http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/User:MihalOrela 14:14, 24 November 2011 (UTC)

== OpenClinica page analysis (a 'wishlist' for OpenClinica) ==
The web page analysis software [http://developer.yahoo.com/yslow/ YSlow] and [http://code.google.com/speed/page-speed/ Page Speed] both report that in the default setup, OpenClinica application pages could be further optimised.
===Resolutions to the page issues highlighted below=== *One of the Page Speed issues below should be resolved by [[OpenClinica_User_Manual/UsingAReverseProxy|using a reverse proxy]], 'Leverage browser caching' by adding expires headers.
=== Page Speed Report === Page Speed reports the following issues for the Study Matrix, ListStudySubjects, in Openclinica 3.1.2 (lengthy details removed), see [http://code.google.com/speed/page-speed/docs/rules_intro.html Page Speed] for more details on what is checked. ====Issues==== [Significant performance improvements are possible]Page Speed Score: 45/100 *[Score: 0/100] Combine images into CSS sprites The following images served from dundee.ac.uk should be combined into as few images as possible, using CSS sprites. *[Score: 0/100] Leverage browser caching The following cacheable resources have a short freshness lifetime. Specify an expiry of at least one week in the future for the following resources:
Other issues were found, but weren't listed as red issues.
=== YSlow report === The YSlow report for Openclinica 3.1.2, see [http://developer.yahoo.com/yslow/ YSlow]:
Grade C Overall performance score 75 Ruleset applied: YSlow(V2)
*F Make fewer HTTP requests *F Use a Content Delivery Network (CDN) *F Add Expires headers *B Put CSS at top *D Put JavaScript at bottom *F Minify JavaScript and CSS *C Reduce the number of DOM elements

revision.comment: /* Copyright violation */ Update figures and rules
revision.text:
== Copyright violation ==
Software copyright violation ("Piracy"), involves creating unlicensed duplicates of computer programs, then selling them or using them, even as authentic items. Software application programs that are used without the permission of the owner/manufacturer or obtained illegally are often called pirated software, the proper term would be unlicensed software. It is illegal in the United States and in most countries.
According to the [[w:Business Software Alliance|Business Software Alliance (BSA)]] 2009 report, approximately 41% of all personal computer software is installed illegally. The loss to software vendors is about $50 billion.
{{NOTE|This types of estimations are intrinsically prone to errors. First the source of the reports have an invested interest in amplifying the problem and the cause, toward the goal calling attention to the issue and doing so generate supportive legislation. Second, it implies that not only that the numbers are accurate but that all detected illegal uses directly signifies missed revenue. }} [[File:Pro piracy demonstration.jpg|thumb|Demonstration against Copyright law]] Copyright violation is often represented as theft, this is factually incorrect since nothing is directly subtracted from the owner. It is an infringement of the owner rights that can indeed cause monetary loss by depreciating how the public views the product, since copies may be of inferior quality or compromised (include virus) and reduce legitimate sales (this is however somewhat counter balanced by increased public exposition).
With the widespread violation of copyright, due to the intrusive types of protection schemes, bad legislation and unrealistic duration of copyright, owners and manufactures do not get direct and guaranteed return for their creative work. Programs that have high costs are industrially duplicated used illegally or pirated, this also means that states can not tax these sales.
After interviewing 15,000 computer users from 33 different countries in early 2012, the Business Software Alliance found 57% of the world computer users acknowledge to using pirated software. Most of the users of pirated software are young males in countries with developing economies, such as Venezuela, China and Thailand.
With the expansion of global markets, it is essential that businesses audit their software to lower their risk for copyright violations. Sarbanes-Oxley requires company officers to confirm the integrity of all financial records and to ensure the proper internal controls are in place. Should a company be found guilty of copy right violations the penalties include $150,000 fine per violation and possible prison time for the officers of the company.
=== Copyright law opposition === [[File:Anti-copyright.svg|100px|thumb|Anti-copy Symbol]] One form of defense that right owners (firm or author) of software can use to deter criminals from unlicensed duplicating software is Copyright. This is protection available to the rights owner of a software program, a book, movie, etc. Having this protection gives the author exclusive right to duplicate it. A copyright, depending on local legislation, may last for 95 years of publication or 120 years since the date it was created, whichever comes first. {{clear}}
{{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=170]]
==Annotations== '''''élite'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''the upper class''; ''the rich''; ''the privileged members of society''. This French [[wikt:élite|term]] is now a naturalized English word. The literal translation is ''[[wikt:elect|elect]]''. '''''Crème de la crème'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''the best of the best''. This French [[wikt:crème de la crème|expression]] is now a naturalized English phrase. The literal translation is ''cream of the cream'', the cream being the richest part of milk. '''Whitehatted ''chef'' like a rabbi'''{{spaces|5}}On certain ceremonial occasions, rabbis wear white cylindrical hats similar to the traditional white cap of a French chef.Gifford (1988) 182. Bloom may be thinking of the ''[[w:Shtreimel|shtreimel]]'', which comes in several varieties, not all of them worn exclusively by rabbis. The ''shtreimel'' of Rabbi [[w:Menachem Mendel Schneersohn|Menachem Mendel Schneersohn]] was made of white velvet and was not unlike a [[w:Chef's uniform|chef's white hat]], or ''[[w:Toque|toque blanche]]''. '''''chef'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''the head cook in a kitchen or establishment''. This French [[wikt:chef|term]] is now a naturalized English word and is not usually italicized. The literal translation is ''head''. '''Curly cabbage ''à la duchesse de Parme'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Curly kale cooked in a style popularized by the Duchess of Parma''. Gifford identifies this as ''Baked savoy cabbage with a stuffing of ground veal, herbs, bread crumbs, etc''.Gifford (1988) 182. But ''curly cabbage'' is a literal translation of ''chou frisé'', the French name for [[w:Kale|curly kale]]. Auguste Morel, who worked on the authorized French translation of ''Ulysses'', translated Joyce's ''Curly cabbage'' as ''Chou frisé''.{{cite book |title=Ulysse |last=Joyce |first=James |others=Auguste Morel, Stuart Gilbert (trans.) |year=1929 |publisher=La Maison des Amis des Livres |location=Paris}} In 1816 the estranged wife of Napoleon Bonaparte [[w:Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma|Marie Louise]] became Duchess of Parma. She introduced the manners and ''cuisine'' of the French court to Italy, and her tastes made a lasting impression on local dishes. '''''Du, de, la'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Of the, of, the''.Gifford (1988) 182. ''Du'' is a contraction of the preposition ''de'' (''of'' or ''from'') and the masculine [[w:Article (grammar)|definite article]] ''le'' (''the''). ''De la'' is the feminine equivalent of ''du''. Some editions of ''Ulysses'' omit the comma after ''de''. The Corrected Text omits all three commas from this sentence.Gabler (1984) 144. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lestrygonians/166|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lestrygonians/168|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=174]]
==Annotations== '''''Don Giovanni, a cenar teco M'invitasti'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Don Giovanni, you invited me to dine with you''.Gifford (1988) 185.
Thornton (1968) 148. These words are spoken by the statue of the Commendatore in the final scene of [[w:Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart's]] opera ''[[w:Don Giovanni|Don Giovanni]]''. In the opening scene of the opera, Don Giovanni kills the Commendatore, who is trying to protect his daughter Donna Anna from the Don's attempted rape. In Act II, Scene 3, the Don comes across a statue of the Commendatore in a graveyard, and he mockingly invites it to dinner. '''''A cenar teco'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''To dine with you''. '''What does that ''teco'' mean?'''{{spaces|5}} (''Italian'') ''With you''.Gifford (1988) 185. '''''The rum the rumdum'''''{{spaces|5}} The Commendatore's next line is: ''E son venuto'' (''And I have come''), which has the same rhythm as Bloom's ''The rum the rumdum''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lestrygonians/170|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Lestrygonians/172|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

page.title: Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Scylla and Charybdis/177

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=180]]
==Annotations== '''''Orchestral Satan, weeping many a rood ... fatto trombetta'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') Stephen here conflates two lines from [[w:John Milton|Milton's]] ''[[w:Paradise Lost|Paradise Lost]]'' and one line from [[w:Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[w:Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]''.Gifford (1988) 194.
Thornton (1968) 153. The lines from Milton refer first to Satan's huge bulk as he lies prone in the burning lake of Hell and then to the tears he lets drop as he is about to address his fallen angels: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Paradise Lost 1:196 ... 1:620'''''[http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/26/pg26.txt John Milton, ''Paradise Lost''.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Lay floating many a rood...'' ''Tears such as angels weep burst forth....'' |} The line from Dante is the closing line of the twenty-first canto of the ''Inferno''. It refers not to Satan but to another infernal demon Barbaricca, one of the ''[[w:Malabranche (Divine Comedy)|Malabranche]]''. Barbaricca is the leader of a troop of demons who escort Dante and Virgil through the fifth of the ''[[w:Malebolge|Malebolge]]'' that comprise the Eighth Circle of Hell. His fellow demons salute him by sticking out their tongues and he responds by farting: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Inferno 21:139'''''[http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/1009/pg1009.txt Dante, ''Inferno''.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''ed elli avea del cul fatto trombetta.'' | ''and he made a trumpet of his arse.'' |} Stephen has modernized Dante's spelling of ''elli'' (''he'') '''and one more to hail him : ''ave, rabbi'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''hail, master.''Gifford (1988) 195. The words, spoken by Judas just before he kisses and betrays Christ, are taken from the Latin [[w:Vulgate|Vulgate]] translation of Matthew 26:49.[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2026&version=KJV Matthew 26.] Cranly is presumably being identified here by Joyce as Judas. Joyce and J. F. Byrne (the model for Cranly) became estranged in 1902, shortly before Joyce met [[w:Oliver St. John Gogarty|Oliver St. John Gogarty]] (the model for Buck Mulligan), though it was Byrne who felt that he had been betrayed by Joyce.Ellmann (1983) 116-117. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/176|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/178|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
<includeonly>{{#if:{{{ping|}}}|ping|
{{Subjects/allbooks|subject={{{subject}}}|origin={{{origin}}}|diagnose={{{diagnose|}}}}}
{{#if:{{parsable|{{Subject:{{{subject}}}}}}}
|
{{#if:{{#titleparts:{{Subject:{{{subject}}}}}|1|2}}
  |{{subjects/{{subjects/name next|{{{n}}}}}
     |subject={{#titleparts:{{Subject:{{{subject}}}}}|1|2}}
     |origin={{{subject}}}
     |n={{#expr:{{{n}}} + 1}}
     |diagnose={{{diagnose|}}}}}}}
{{#if:{{#titleparts:{{Subject:{{{subject}}}}}|1|3}}
  |{{subjects/{{subjects/name next|{{{n}}}}}
     |subject={{#titleparts:{{Subject:{{{subject}}}}}|1|3}}
     |origin={{{subject}}}
     |n={{#expr:{{{n}}} + 1}}
     |diagnose={{{diagnose|}}}}}}}
|
[[Category:Attention needed (allbooks)]]
{{#if:{{{diagnose|}}}|{{Subjects/diagnose subject|subject={{{subject}}}|origin={{{origin}}}}}}}}}}}</includeonly><noinclude>
{{Documentation|Template:Subjects/0/doc}}</noinclude>

{{Documentation subpage}} <!-- PLEASE ADD CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE -->
{{high-risk}}<!-- this documentation is used for the entire series of templates subjects/n --> This is one of a series of sub-templates of {{tl|subjects}} that add the current page to [[Template:Allbooks category|allbooks categories]]. === Usage === There are three required parameters and two optional. One of the required parameters may be blank. * {{((}}{ping}{{))}} — Optional. If non-blank, this template is only being called to make sure it exists. * {{((}}{subject}{{))}} — Required. Names a subject to whose allbooks category this page should be added. * {{((}}{origin}{{))}} — Required. Names the previously visited subject, ''if any'', which provided the value for {{((}}{subject}{{))}}; may be blank. * {{((}}{n}{{))}} — Required. An integer that names this template. The first template in the series is called 0, the second is 1, and so on. * {{((}}{diagnose}{{))}} — Optional. If non-blank, diagnostic messages are provided when errors are detected, together with suggestions to fix the problem and buttons to act on the suggestions. If {{((}}{ping}{{))}} is non-blank, this template simply returns "ping" without doing anything else. This makes it possible for each template in the series to look for the [[Template:Subjects/name next|next]] template in the series without using expensive parser function {{((}}#ifexist:{{))}} (instead, simply ping the next template and compare the result to "ping").
Otherwise, this template first requests the current page be added to the allbooks category associated with {{nowrap|Subject:{{((}}{subject}{{))}}}}, via {{tl|Subjects/allbooks}}. Then it checks to see whether the subject page itself exists and is suitably formatted for extraction of its parent parameters. If all is well, it extracts the parent parameters from the subject page, and passes each of them in turn to the next sub-template in the series. Otherwise, it adds the current page to {{nowrap|[[:Category:Attention needed (allbooks)]]}}, and if in addition {{((}}{diagnose}{{))}} is non-blank, also calls {{nowrap|{{tl|subjects/diagnose subject}}}}.
When calling the next template in the series, the identity of the next template is determined via {{nowrap|{{tl|subjects/name next}}}}, which detects when there are no more templates available in the series and in that case diverts the call to {{nowrap|{{tl|subjects/upper bound}}}}.
=== See also === * {{tl|subjects/leaf}} <includeonly> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE, THANKS -->
[[Category:Template subpages]] </includeonly>

{{tmbox|type=notice|text='''Please help <u>''improve''</u> Wikibooks'''.
Your [[Special:Contributions/82.33.141.185|recent edits]] are considered unconstructive by fellow contributors. Please read [[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks?]] for a description of what we allow. You can ask questions or ask for help in the [[WB:HELP|Assistance Reading Room]]. Please use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] for experimenting with the wiki software in the future. Thanks. --[[User:Jomegat|Jomegat]] ([[User talk:Jomegat|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Jomegat|contribs]]) 21:35, 24 November 2011 (UTC)}}

Welcome, Reyes A! {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on discussion pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * Learn how to [[Using Wikibooks|use Wikibooks]] and learn more about the community. * [[WB:CCO|Explore]], [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/General|general reading room]] or your project in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Projects|project reading room]]. If you have any questions, you can ask in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Assistance|assistance reading room]] or contact me personally.

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Master tongue!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:10, 24 November 2011 (UTC)
== Learn Hawaiian Textbook for Dedicated Students == Hi, An anonymous IP user has requested the deletion of this book. I am thinking that this was you and you hadn't logged in? You were the only contributor to the book before the deletion was requested so if you wish to delete it there is no problem.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:54, 25 November 2011 (UTC) == Hawaiian- For the Dedicated Learner == Hello there, Master tongue. I read your user page and I congratulate you on your quest to learn more than 58 languages. Very impressive! Your book, Hawaiian- For the Dedicated Learner, is wonderful so far! However, I do have a few issues to bring up with you regarding the book. First and foremost, wikibooks already has a book titled [[Hawaiian]], so I will be proposing a merge of your book into that one. I do not mean to offend you, but that book's title is more appropriate for the Wikibooks platform. However, I am very dedicated to preserving the content you have already created within your book, including your navigation plan, and I hope you do continue to make content for the [[Hawaiian]] wikibook. --[[User:Thereen|Thereen]] ([[User talk:Thereen|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Thereen|contribs]]) 05:51, 27 November 2011 (UTC) == Irritation == You know what really bugs me? When you go from website to website, looking for a legit one where you can learn a language, but all the ones you can find are the same: they show you phrases that might/will come in handy if/when you travel to the place where that language is spoken. Almost every site lacks the grammar behind the language unless one searches for "Grammar". If you are not aware yet, let me inform you that there is so much more to language than just words. Grammar is a large part of it all, along with pronunciation and slang/common speach. So many websites think it's ok to just say, "Ok, memorize these phrases and you'll be good," but it doesn't mean anything if you don't know '''how''' to use that information. That really gets on my nerves! Uhg! ([[User:Master tongue|Master tongue]] ([[User talk:Master tongue|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Master tongue|contribs]]) 04:50, 10 January 2012 (UTC)) ==Important Note for Those Interested in Learning Irish...== For those interested in learning Irish, I have found a fantastic website that is entirely self tought, allowing you to go at your own pace: http://www.irishpage.com/irishpeople/index.htm It really is a wonderful site, and I have been enjoying it. It shows pronunciation, and explains everything from the beginning, starting with easy, basic notes, to more advanced lessons. Did I mention that there are 128 lessons here?!? What's more, there is an internal link to a different page, in a different course with audio, yet one must pay to use that one. (I still recomend looking it over a bit though!) And with that, I say, Good Luck! to everyone in their language studies! ([[User:Master tongue|Master tongue]] ([[User talk:Master tongue|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Master tongue|contribs]]) 23:48, 11 January 2012 (UTC)) == Hawaiian book == Master tongue, there are a few points of confusion I have over the content in your Hawaiian wikibook. Check out: [[Talk:Hawaiian/Lesson_One]]. [[Special:Contributions/75.36.227.38|75.36.227.38]] ([[User talk:75.36.227.38|discuss]]) 06:30, 5 August 2012 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Bpuklich!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:11, 24 November 2011 (UTC)

revision.text: My name is Elaine Kohrman (Ekohrman) and I am an instructor of Biology at Somerset Community College in Somerset, Kentucky, USA. I mainly teach Human Anatomy and Physiology courses for Allied Health students. I teach in a rural, low income area and am very interested in open education resources.
