page.title: IB Environmental Systems and Societies/Measuring abiotic components of the system

revision.text:
====2.2 Measuring abiotic components of the system==== ----
'''2.2.1 List the significant abiotic (physical)factors of an ecosystem.''' :* PH, Temperature, Light intensity, Salinity, Turbidity, Dissolved oxygen
'''2.2.2 Describe and evaluate methods for measuring at least three abiotic (physical) factors within an ecosystem.''' :*PH - PH meter :*Temperature - Thermometer (C degrees) :*Dissolved oxygen - Oxygen meter (PPM) :*Light intensity - Light meter (LUX) :*Salinity - Salinity meter (ppt) :*Turbidity - Secchi circle (Visibility)
:*marine—salinity, dissolved oxygen, wave action :*freshwater—turbidity, temperature, dissolved oxygen :*terrestrial—temperature,wind speed, particle size, slope, soil moisture, drainage, mineral content. {{BookCat}}

page.title: IB Environmental Systems and Societies/Measuring biotic components of the system

revision.text:
====2.3 Measuring biotic components of the system==== ----
'''2.3.1 Construct simple keys and use published keys for the identification of organisms.''' :* Dichotomous Keys
'''2.3.2 Describe and evaluate methods for estimating abundance of organisms.'''
'''2.3.3 Describe and evaluate methods for estimating the biomass of trophic levels in a community.'''
'''2.3.4 Define the term diversity.''' :* Diversity is often considered as a function of two components: the number of different species and the relative numbers of individuals of each species.
'''2.3.5 Apply Simpson’s diversity index and outline its significance.'''
:* Formula: D = N(N − 1)/ ∑ n(n − 1)
Where: :*D = diversity index :*N = total number of organisms of all species found :*n = number of individuals of a particular species
:*D is a measure of species richness. A high value of D suggests a stable and ancient site, and a low value of D could suggest pollution, recent colonization or agricultural management. The index is normally used in studies of vegetation but can also be applied to comparisons of animal(or even all species) diversity. {{BookCat}}

====2.4 Biomes==== ----
'''2.4.1 Define the term biome.''' :* A collection of ecosystems sharing similar climatic conditions; for example, tundra, tropical rainforest, desert. :* Int: Biomes usually cross national boundaries (biomes do not stop at a border; for example, the Sahara, tundra, tropical rainforests).
'''2.4.2 Explain the distribution, structure and relative productivity of tropical rainforests, deserts, tundra and any other biome.'''
- Tropical Rainforests: :* High productivity :* High precipitation (2500 mm yr¹) throughout the year :* High insolation :* High temperature (26 ʻC) :* Good nutrient cycling = High rate of decomposure :* Highest NPP
- Temperate Forests: :* Medium productivity :* 4 seasons (Insolation and temperature varies) :* Good growing season in the summer but limited in the winter :* High temperatures and insolation in the summer = Greater productivity :* Rainfall between 500 and 1500 mm yr¹ :* Second highest NPP
- Tundra: :* Low productivity :* Lowest of precipitation (50 mm yr¹) :* Low insolation (Days are shorter) :* Low Temperature :* Poor nutrient cycling because itʼs locked in the permafrost therefore low rate of decomposure :* For 1-2 months the productivity is very high because the sun is up for almost the whole day
- Deserts: :* Very low productivity :* Low precipitation (Under 250 mm yr¹) :* High insolation, but all water is evaporated or absorbed by the ground :* Hot days & Cold nights :* Low nutrient cycle :* Species adapted to survive
- Grassland: :*Wide diversity, but low levels of productivity :* Enough precipitation to prevent deserts forming, but not enough to support forests :* Nutrient cycle is sufficient :* Insolation, precipitation and evaporation rates are balanced :* Grass can grow under the surface even in cold periods, waiting to emerge until the ground warms {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=250]]
==Annotations== '''Is that her? ... yes, sitting with his ex'''{{spaces|5}}''Is that Lady Dudley? ... yes, sitting with her husband, his excellency the Lord Lieutenant, [[w:William Ward, 2nd Earl of Dudley|William Humble Ward, Earl of Dudley]].'' See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Wandering_Rocks/242|242.03]]. '''''eau de Nil'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''water of the Nile''.Gifford (1988) 295. ''[[wikt:eau de nil|Eau de Nil]]'' is the name of a pale yellowish green colour. Here it refers to the colour of the Lord Lieutenant's uniform, contrasted with Lady Dudley's pearl grey dress. '''''beau'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''[[wikt:beau|boyfriend]]''; ''male lover''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=255]]
==Annotations== '''Mooney's ''en ville'' and in Mooney's ''sur mer'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Mooney's-in-town and in Mooney's-on-the-sea''.Gifford (1988) 297. Lenehan is whimsically referring to two public houses in the city centre:Thoms, ''Official Directory of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland: Dublin'' (1903) pp. 1407 and 1481.
Ian Gunn & Clive Hart, ''James Joyce's Dublin'' (2004) p.119. :'''J. G. Mooney & Co., Wine and Spirit Merchants, 1 Lower Abbey Street.''' :'''Gerald Mooney, Publican, 3 Eden Quay.''' The latter is situated on one of the River Liffey's quays — hence it is ''sur mer'' — while the former is "landlocked". See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Aeolus/138|138.13]]. '''''élite'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''a [[wikt:elite|group]] of people with superior intellectual, social or economic status in society''. The members of Lenehan's ''élite'' of Erin are hardly superior to their fellow Irishmen in any of these categories. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Nelson2012!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? [[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=263]]
==Annotations== '''''M'appari'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''There appeared to me''.Gifford (1988) 300.
Thornton (1968) 245. These are the opening words of an Italian translation of Lionel's aria in Act III of [[w:Friedrich von Flotow|Friedrich von Flotow's]] German opera ''[[w:Martha (opera)|Martha]]''. The correct spelling is ''[[wikt:apparì|M’apparì]]''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/245|245.24]]. '''''M'appari tutt'amor :'''''
'''''Il mio sguardo l'incontr''[''ò'']'' ...'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''All love appeared to me : My eyes encountered her''.Gifford (1988) 300.
Thornton (1968) 245. These are the opening words of an Italian translation of Lionel's aria in Act III of [[w:Friedrich von Flotow|Friedrich von Flotow's]] German opera ''[[w:Martha (opera)|Martha]]''. The correct spelling is ''[[wikt:apparì|M’apparì ...]]''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/245|245.24]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/259|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/261|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=264]]
==Annotations== '''''Sonambula'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Sonnambula''. '''''Sonnambula'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''Sleepwalker''.Gifford (1988) 301.
Thornton (1968) 245. The allusion is to ''[[w:La sonnambula|La sonnambula]]'', the opera by [[w:Vincenzo Bellini|Bellini]] from which the aria ''Tutto è sciolto'' (''All is Lost'') is taken. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/245|245.22]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/260|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/262|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=270]]
==Annotations== '''''Blumenlied'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''Flower Song''.Gifford (1988) 304.
Thornton (1968) 248. Among the hundreds of songs with this title, the most famous are settings of the poem ''Du Bist wie eine Blume'' (''You Are Like a Flower'') by [[w:Heinrich Heine|Heinrich Heine]].[http://www.umass.edu/wsp/reference/languages/german/readings/heine.html Heinrich Heine, ''Du Bist wie eine Blume''.] The poem first appeared in 1825 in Heine's collection ''Das Buch der Lieder'' (''The Book of Songs''). The most celebrated setting was made by [[w:Robert Schumann|Schumann]] in 1840 in his song cycle ''Myrthen'' (''Myrtles''), Op. 25.[http://imslp.org/wiki/Myrthen,_Op.25_%28Schumann,_Robert%29 Robert Schumann, ''Myrthen''.] The poem has also been set to music by [[w:Franz Liszt|Franz Liszt]] and [[w:Hugo Wolf|Hugo Wolf]]. One of Heine's best known poems is ''Die Lorelei'', which tells of a [[w:Siren|siren-like]] creature on the Rhine who lures sailors to their deaths with her beauty and her singing. '''The name'''{{spaces|5}}The German ''Blumenlied'' (''Flower Song'') is a play on ''Bloom''. '''Playing it slow'''{{spaces|5}}Schumann's ''Du Bist wie eine Blume'' has the tempo marking ''[[w:Glossary of musical terminology|Langsam]]'' (''Slow''). ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/266|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/268|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=273]]
==Annotations== '''''quis est homo :'' Mercadante'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Who is the man?''Gifford (1988) 306.
Thornton (1968) 250. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/079|079.09]]. Bloom seems to be confusing Mercadante with Rossini. Earlier, he mentioned Mercadante's ''Le sette ultime parole di Nostro Signore Gesù Cristo'' (''The Seven Last Words of Our Lord Jesus Christ'') immediately after alluding to Rossini's ''Stabat Mater''. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/278|278.29]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Eumaeus/614|614.28]], where Mercadante and Meyerbeer are confused. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/269|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/271|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=275]]
==Annotations== '''''in nomine Domini ... mea culpa'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''in the name of the Lord ... through my fault''.Gifford (1988) 307. Carroll Malone's lyrics for ''The Croppy Boy'' include the following stanza, in which the Croppy Boy begins his [[w:Sacrament of Penance (Catholic Church)|confession]]: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''The Croppy Boy'''''[http://www.james-joyce-music.com/song16_lyrics.html ''The Croppy Boy''] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''The youth has knelt to tell his sins:'' Nomine Dei'', the youth begins!'' ''At ''mea culpa'' he beats his breast,'' ''And in broken murmurs he speaks the rest.'' | 13 14 15 16 |} The Croppy Boy would have begun the Rite of Confession by making the [[w:Sign of the Cross|Sign of the Cross]] while reciting the [[w:Trinitarian formula|Trinitarian Formula]]: ''In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti, Amen'' (''In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, Amen''). He would recite the ''[[w:Confiteor|Confiteor]]'', which includes the line, ''mea culpa, mea culpa'' (''through my fault, through my fault''), ''after'' confessing his sins.[http://books.google.ie/books?id=T0BFAAAAcAAJ ''Rituale Romanum'' 62 ff.] The Croppy Boy, then, would not have spoken the words ''Nomine Dei'', while his ''mea culpa'' would have come after the litany of his sins. Furthermore, the Latin expressions Bloom, Goulding and Pat are alleged to hear are not part of the traditional lyrics. It is possible that Ben Dollard is singing a variant text, or simply misremembering the lyrics; Zack Bowen believes that the mistake is Joyce's.{{cite book |title=Musical Allusions in the Works of James Joyce: Early Poetry through Ulysses |last=Bowen |first=Zack R. |year=1974 |publisher=State University of New York Press |location=Albany |isbn=0-87395-248-0 |pages=196-197}} It is curious that the text of ''Ulysses'' has the Latin expression ''in nomine domini'' (''in the name of the Lord'') instead of ''nomine dei'' (''in God's name''), while giving the English translation of the latter. Perhaps the translation is Bloom's. '''''corpusnomine'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') A nonsense word Bloom has concocted from ''corpus'' (''body'') and ''nomine'' (''in the name''). He has just heard Ben Dollard sing the latter; this reminds him of the expression ''Corpus Domini'' (''the Body of Our Lord''), which he heard in St Andrew's Church on Westland Row earlier in the day ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Lotus_Eaters/077|077.31]]); he is also reminded of the Latin he heard in the mortuary chapel in Prospect Cemetery during Paddy Dignam's Burial Service, which had prompted another of his Latin concoctions, ''Dominenamine'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Hades/100|100.01]]).Gifford (1988) 307.
Thornton (1968) 251. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/246|246.16]] for an earlier variant in this episode. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/266|266.18]] for a similar instance, and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/277|277.37]] for a variation on ''dominenamine''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/271|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Sirens/273|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=280]]
==Annotations== '''''Cloche. Sonnez la!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Bell. Sound the!'' See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/245|245.17-18]]. '''''nominedomine'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') Another of Bloom's nonsensical Latin concoctions.Gifford (1988) 310.
Thornton (1968) 253. This one is derived from the phrase ''in nomine Domini'' (''In the name of the Lord''), which occurred earlier in this episode at [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/272|272.17]]. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/246|246.16]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/272|272.20]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

== Welcome! ==

'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.

* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 12:16, 26 November 2011 (UTC)
== Muggles' Guide apparation == I hope you'll forgive my asking, but why? The correct spelling, as seen repeatedly in the UK HP books, is appar''a''tion, to distinguish it from "apparition" which is equivalent to a ghost. I don't like to revert so large a change without at least some understanding as to why it was done, and agreement on the correct course, so as to prevent an edit war. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 18:55, 27 November 2011 (UTC) :Actually, having looked at the books, I will concede your point. But: I will ask you to revert your edits to that page, and ask for a quick delete of the page you created, or I can do that if you'd rather; and then I will move the page and correct the many references to it. That way we retain the edit history. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 21:49, 27 November 2011 (UTC) ::That would be great! Thanks. [[User:RunningBlind|RunningBlind]] ([[User talk:RunningBlind|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RunningBlind|contribs]]) 01:06, 28 November 2011 (UTC) :::No problem. I have reverted your edits partially (enough so we won't get redlinks on Apparition when the page gets deleted), and will move the page and correct the links once the delete is done. After you've been editing for a while, you'll automatically get Move permission as well... and also will be able to mark pages for quality. One of the advantages of having a named account. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 04:54, 28 November 2011 (UTC) ::::All right. [[User:RunningBlind|RunningBlind]] ([[User talk:RunningBlind|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RunningBlind|contribs]]) 04:58, 28 November 2011 (UTC) :::::This will take some time -- there are over a hundred uses of the link to clean up. But we're started anyway... [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 01:11, 29 November 2011 (UTC) ::::::And that looks like that has it. I hope. [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 18:21, 3 December 2011 (UTC) :::::::Great! I'm glad that I helped bring this up and it feels good that it's fixed. [[User:RunningBlind|RunningBlind]] ([[User talk:RunningBlind|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RunningBlind|contribs]]) 19:26, 3 December 2011 (UTC) == Muggles' Guide quality == Just a quick note -- I see you now have your reviewer tools, congratulations. I should mention that [[User:PNW Raven|PNW Raven]], while very good at drawing out connections and coming up with deeper meanings, has an awful habit of scattering typos and fragments throughout. While I appreciate your additional eyes, I would like to suggest that the top grade not be applied to an article until you've cast a careful eye across it for grammatical errors on Raven's part, and mine -- I'm usually pretty good, but things always sneak by. I assume you know already how to use History to compare versions... [[User:Chazz|Chazz]] ([[User talk:Chazz|talk]]) 07:05, 28 December 2011 (UTC) :That's what I've mostly been doing and I'm pretty good at catching grammar and typos as well as having a very good knowledge of obscure details in the books to catch small mistakes. [[User:RunningBlind|RunningBlind]] ([[User talk:RunningBlind|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/RunningBlind|contribs]]) 05:32, 29 December 2011 (UTC)

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=287]]
==Annotations== '''''a chara'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''friend''. This is the vocative case of the noun ''[[wikt:cara#Irish|cara]]''. '''the mountain gorse ''(Ulex Europeus)'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''[[w:Ulex europaeus|Ulex europaeus]]'' is the scientific name for the evergreen shrub variously known in Ireland as the [[wikt:whin|whin]], [[wikt:furze|furze]] or [[wikt:gorse|gorse]].Gifford (1988) 320. The leaves are spiny but green, while the flowers are yellow. When they wilt, however, the leaves turn ''tawny orange'' in the words of [[w:John Betjeman|John Betjeman]] in ''Cornish Cliffs''.[http://www.sanjeev.net/poetry/betjeman-john/cornish-cliffs-182179.html ''Cornish Cliffs''.] In his essay ''Of Usury'', Francis Bacon describes the yellow headgear worn by Jewish moneylenders as ''orange-tawny''.''The Essays of Francis Bacon, Edited, with Introduction and Notes by Mary Augusta Scott'', New York (1908), pp. 187-188. Gorse is found throughout Ireland.[http://www.wildflowersofireland.net/plant_detail.php?id_flower=109 Wildflowers of Ireland.] When identifying a species through its [[w:Binomial nomenclature|scientific name]], it is now modern usage to capitalize the genus (''Ulex'') but not the species (''europaeus''). ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/283|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/285|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=292]]
==Annotations== '''tantras'''{{spaces|5}}(''Sanskrit'') A ''[[wikt:tantra|tantra]]'' is a Hindu religious text.Gifford (1988) 329. In [[w:Theosophy|Theosophy]], tantras are mystical and magical words comprising rituals associated with black magic or sorcery.[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/296/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p. 296.] '''etheric double'''{{spaces|5}}(''Theosophy'') In [[w:Theosophy|Theosophy]], the ''double'', or ''Astral Body'', is the ethereal counterpart or shadow of a man or animal's physical body.[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/35/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p. 35.]
Gifford (1988) 330. '''jivic rays'''{{spaces|5}}(''Theosophy'') In [[w:Theosophy|Theosophy]], ''jiva'' refers to Life, as the Absolute.[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/153/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p. 153.]
Gifford (1988) 330. It may also refer to the Monad, the immortal part of man which is reincarnated.[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/201/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p. 201.] The adjectival form ''jivic'' appears to be Joyce's own coinage. '''prālāyā'''{{spaces|5}}(''Sanskrit'') ''dissolution''.Gifford (1988) 330. In ''The Theosophical Glossary'', [[w:Helen Blavatsky|Helen Blavatsky]] defines '''Pralaya''' as: ''A period of obscuration or repose—planetary, cosmic or universal—the opposite of Manvantara.''[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/242/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p.242.] In the context of [[w:Theosophy|Theosophy]], ''[[wikt:pralaya|pralaya]]'' refers to the period between death and reincarnation. In transliterating Sanskrit terms from [[w:Devanagari transliteration|Devanagari]] to Roman script, a [[wikt:macron|macron]] is placed over a long vowel. There are no long vowels in ''pralaya''; Joyce's macrons here and below (lines 16 and 19) are whimsical. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/041|041.04]]. '''tālāfānā, ālāvātār, hātākāldā, wātāklāsāt'''{{spaces|5}}''telephone, elevator, hot and cold [plumbing], water closet''.Gifford (1988) 330. The whimsical spellings and [[wikt:macron|macrons]] parody the [[w:Theosophical Society|Theosophists']] predilection for Sanskrit terms. See ''prālāyā'' above. '''Māyā'''{{spaces|5}}(''Sanskrit'') ''Illusion''. In both Hindu philosophy and Theosophy ''māyā'' refers to the idea that the physical world of sense perception is not part of true reality.[http://archive.org/stream/theosophicalglos00blav#page/195/mode/1up Helen Blavatsky, ''The Theosophical Glossary'', p. 195.] In this case, Joyce's whimsical [[wikt:macron|macrons]] are justified, but it is probably fair to say he would have added them even if they were not. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/288|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/290|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=295]]
==Annotations== '''''corpora cavernosa'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''cavernous bodies''.Gifford (1988) 332. ''[[w:Corpus cavernosum penis|Corpora cavernosa]]'' is the anatomical name for two masses of erectile tissue in the penis; a [[w:penile erection|penile erection]] occurs when the cavities in these bodies (and in a third body, the ''[[w:corpus spongiosum penis|corpus spongiosum penis]]'') fill with blood and become distended. '''''in articulo mortis per diminutionem capitis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''at the moment of death caused by the decrease of the head''.Gifford (1988) 332. Bloom's medical Latin is improvised; ''[[w:Capitis diminutio|capitis diminutio]]'' is actually a legal term meaning ''the loss of one's political rights'', whereas Bloom means ''the breaking of the neck'' (''per frangentem cervicis''). ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/291|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/293|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=296]]
==Annotations== '''''Sinn Fein ... Sinn fein amhain'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Sinn féin ... Sinn féin amháin''. Gabler (1984) did not emend it, however, on the grounds that the errors were Joyce's and not typos. When an early draft of this episode was published in ''[[w:The Little Review|The Little Review]]'', it appeared exactly as it does on the page above.[http://dl.lib.brown.edu/repository2/repoman.php?verb=render&id=1299770729203127&view=pageturner&pageno=52 ''The Little Review'', Volume 6, Number 7 (November 1919), p. 50.] '''''Sinn féin ... Sinn féin amháin!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Ourselves ... Ourselves alone!''Gifford (1988) 333.
Thornton (1968) 269. Watchword of Irish nationalists at the turn of the century. According to Gifford these words occur in the refrain of [[w:Timothy Daniel Sullivan|Timothy Daniel Sullivan's]] patriotic song ''The West's Awake'', though the only song of this name that I am aware of is by [[w:Thomas Davis (Young Irelander)|Thomas Osbourne Davis]], and it does not include these words. Thornton mentions a song called ''Sinn Fein, Sinn Fein Amhain'' by O'Higgins.{{cite book |title=Songs in the Works of James Joyce |last=Hodgart |first=Matthew |coauthors=Mabel Worthington |year=1959 |publisher=Columbia University Press |location=New York |isbn= |page=202 |url=http://books.google.ie/books?id=RNxaAAAAMAAJ&q=Sinn#search_anchor |accessdate=06-12-2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/292|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/294|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=298]]
==Annotations== '''''Gladiolus Cruentus'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''[[w:gladiolus|Gladiolus cruentus]]'' is the scientific name for a flowering plant known as the blood-red gladiolus on account of the colour of its flowers. The plant is a native of South Africa. Its name could be translated as ''little blood-stained sword'', appropriate for the favourite flower of an executioner.Gifford (1988) 335-336. Gifford calls it a fictional species, but it was identified by the British botanist [[w:Thomas Moore (botanist)|Thomas Moore]] in the 19th century. When identifying a species through its [[w:Binomial nomenclature|scientific name]], it is now modern usage to capitalize the genus (''Gladiolus'') but not the species (''cruentus''). See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/284|284.13]]. '''''hoch'''''{{spaces|5}}(''German'') ''noble'', ''sublime''.Gifford (1988) 336. ''[[wikt:hoch|Hoch]]'' is used in German toasts and salutations. The German for ''Long live the king!'' is ''Hoch lebe der König'', while ''Hoch der Kaiser!'' means ''Up the Kaiser!'' '''''banzai'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Japanese'') ''ten thousand years''.Gifford (1988) 336. ''[[wikt:banzai|Banzai]]'' is used as both a battle cry and a salutation to the emperor. '''''eljen'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata''). This should be spelled ''éljen''. '''''éljen'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Hungarian'') ''long live...!''Gifford (1988) 336. This is the third perlson singular, present subjunctive indefinite of the verb ''[[wikt:él|él]]'' (''to live''). '''''zivio'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Serbo-Croatian''). This should be spelled ''živio''. '''''živio'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Serbo-Croatian'') ''long live...!'', ''cheers!''.Gifford (1988) 336. This is the optative mood (here identical to the active past participle, masculine singular) of the verb ''[[wikt:žívjeti|žívjeti]]'' (''to live''). '''''chinchin'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Pidgin English'') This is a traditional salutation and toast from the Far East.Gifford (1988) 336. ''[[wikt:chin-chin|Chinchin]]'' is probably of Chinese origin. '''''polla kronia'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Modern Greek'') ''many happy returns''.Gifford (1988) 336. The usual form in Modern Greek is ''[[wikt:χρόνια πολλά|χρόνια πολλά]]'', so perhaps Joyce's text could be amended to: ''khrónia pollá''. '''''hiphip'''''{{spaces|5}}(''American'') From ''[[wikt:hip hip hooray|hip hip hooray]]''.Gifford (1988) 336. '''''vive'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''long live...!''Gifford (1988) 336. '''''Allah'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Arabic'') ''God''.Gifford (1988) 336. As an interjection' ''Allah!'' is generally used to express surprise, not to acclaim a leader. '''''evviva'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Italian'') ''long live...!''Gifford (1988) 336. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/294|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/296|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=300]]
==Annotations== '''''fiancée'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''a woman who is engaged to be married''. As a naturalized English word, ''[[wikt:fiancée|fiancée]]'' is often left unitalicized. '''''entourage'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''one's attendants or followers''. As a naturalized English word, ''[[wikt:entourage|entourage]]'' is not usually italicized. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/296|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/298|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=301]]
==Annotations== '''''pro bono publico'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''[[wikt:pro bono publico|for the public good]].Gifford (1988) 338. '''''sobriquet'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''nickname''. As a naturalized English word, ''[[wikt:sobriquet|sobriquet]]'' is often left unitalicized. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/297|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/299|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

Created page with "[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=303]]
==Annotations== ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="ba..."

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=304]]
==Annotations== '''''Slan leat'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Slán leat''. '''''Slán leat'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Goodbye''.Gifford (1988) 340. In Irish the literal meaning of ''[[wikt:slán leat|slán leat]]'' is ''safety with you'', or ''may you go safely''. It is a valediction addressed by the person remaining to one who is departing. I am not aware of its ever being used as a drinking toast. The traditional Irish toast is ''[[wikt:sláinte|Sláinte]]'', which means ''Health!'' It is possible that Joyce is suggesting that the Citizen is not as fluent in the language as he would have us believe. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/307|307.35]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/300|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/302|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=305]]
==Annotations== '''Nannan's'''{{spaces|5}}Nickname for Joseph Nannetti, MP for Dublin College Green (1901-1915).[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/people/mr-joseph-nannetti/ Mr Joseph Nannetti (Hansard).] See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Aeolus/115|115.32]]. '''''The Sluagh na h-Eireann'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: The ''Sluagh na hÉireann''. '''''Sluagh na hÉireann'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''The Legion of Ireland'', or ''The Irish Brigade''.Gifford (1988) 341. ''Sluagh na hÉireann'' was a patriotic body that promoted the revival of Irish games and customs. It has been described as: ''a short-lived nationalist federation designed to combine the energies of the [[w:Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] and the [[w:Gaelic League|Gaelic League]].[http://www.nli.ie/pdfs/mss%20lists/156_SweetmanPapers.pdf Owen McGee & Harriet Wheelock (compilers), ''Sweetman Family Papers'', National Library of Ireland, Dublin (2010), p. 86.] On 16 June 1904 Joseph Nannetti complained to Parliament on their behalf that Gaelic sports had been banned from the Phoenix Park by the Commisioners of Police, while the foreign sport of polo was permitted.[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1904/jun/16/polo-in-phoenix-park ''Hansard'' 16 June 1904.] The question was raised again on 30 June by Thomas O'Donnell, MP for Kerry West.[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1904/jun/30/phoenix-park-dublin ''Hansard'' 30 June 1904.] Joyce has Nannetti ask his question on 17 June. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/301|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/303|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=306]]
==Annotations== '''''Na bacleis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Ná bac leis''. '''''Ná bac leis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Never mind that.''Gifford (1988) 342. '''''Brian O'Ciarnain's'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Barney Kiernan's''.Gifford (1988) 342. This is, in fact, a macaronic mixture of Irish and English. The Irish form of the name Bernard Kiernan is, ''Brian Ó Ciarnáin''. '''''Sraid na Bretaine Bheag'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Sráid na Breataine Bheag''. '''''Sráid na Breataine Bheag'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Little Britain Street''.Gifford (1988) 342. This means ''Britain Street Little'', rather than ''The Street of Little Britain'', though it is probably fair to say that Joyce set this episode on this street on account of the pun: the New Ireland the Citizen and his ilk wish to establish is just a Little Britain.[http://www.geograph.ie/photo/1196043 Little Britain Street.] In Irish, ''Little Britain'' (''an Bhreatain Bheag'') actually means Wales or Brittany. '''''Sluagh na h-Eireann'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Sluagh na hÉireann''. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/302|302.27]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/302|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/304|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=310]]
==Annotations== '''''compos mentis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') A legal expression meaning ''[[wikt:compos mentis|of sound mind]]'', ''sane''.Gifford (1988) 345. '''A pishogue, if you know what that is.'''{{spaces|5}}Clearly, the Citizen does not know what that is. A ''[[wikt:pishogue|pishogue]]'' is a magic spell. The [[wikt:Hiberno English|Hiberno-English]] word he is looking for is ''[[wikt:pithogue|pithogue]]'', from the Irish ''[[wikt:piteog|piteog]]'', which means ''an effeminate man'', ''a dandy'', ''a sissy'', or (in modern usage) ''a homosexual'', which is possibly what lies behind the Citizen's insult. The term ''pishogue'' is never applied to individuals.Gifford (1988) 345. Gifford, in common with most annotators, does not appreciate the Citizen's mistake. It is possible that the mistake is Joyce's rather than the Citizen's. The two words occur on the same page of Father Dineen's ''Irish-English Dictionary'' (first edition). Joyce certainly knew this work; it was first published in 1904, the year in which ''Ulysses'' is set, and Dineen appears in ''Scylla and Charybdis'' ([[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/202|202.31-32]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Scylla_and_Charybdis/206|206.30]]).{{cite book |title=Foclóir Gaedhilge agus Béarla: An Irish-English Dictionary |last=Dineen |first=Patrick S. |year=1904 |publisher=M. H. Gill & Son Ltd. |location=Dublin |isbn= |page=508 |url=http://www.ucc.ie/celt/Dinneen1sted.html}} If the mistake is the Citizen's, it is another indication that he is not as fluent in the Irish language as he would have us believe. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/301|301.24]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/306|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/308|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment:
Created page with "[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=311]]
==Annotations== ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="ba..."

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=314]]
==Annotations== '''''patois'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''a regional or substandard dialect''. The word ''[[wikt:patois#French|patois]]'' originally meant: ''incomprehensible speech, or rude language'', which is the point the Citizen is making about English. '''''cabinet d'aisance'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''water closet'', ''toilet''.Gifford (1988) 349. '''''Conspuez les Anglais! Perfide Albion!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Down with the English! Treacherous England''.Gifford (1988) 349. ''Conspuez'' derives from the Latin ''[[wikt:conspuere|conspuere]]'' (''to spit on''), though the primary meaning in French is ''to boo''. The latter phrase, ''[[w:Perfidious Albion|Perfidious Albion]]'', is of obscure origin.Thornton (1968) 278-279. Variants of this phrase have been used a byword for English fickleness since the 13th century, while the familiar form was probably coined by Augustin, Marquis of Ximenez in 1793. See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/316|316.26-27]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/310|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/312|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=315]]
==Annotations== '''''Lamh Dearg Abu'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') The correct form is: ''Lámh Dhearg Abú''. '''''Lámh Dhearg Abú'''''{{spaces|5}} (''Irish'') ''Red Hand to Victory''.Gifford (1988) 349.
Thornton (1968) 279. The [[w:Red Hand of Ulster|Red Hand of Ulster]] (''Lámh Dhearg Uladh'') has been a traditional symbol for the province of Ulster and its legendary figures since pagan times. ''Lámh Dhearg Abú'' was the war-cry of the [[w:O'Neill dynasty|O'Neills]], who ruled large tracts of Ireland (including Ulster) since the 5th century. The Red Hand was also depicted on the labels of bottles of Allsop's ale, so the phrase was also used as a drinking cry. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/314|314.33-35]]. '''''Raimeis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Errata'') This should read: ''Ráiméis''. '''''Ráiméis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''Rubbish'', ''Poppycock''.Gifford (1988) 349-350. The Irish word ''[[wikt:ráiméis|ráiméis]]'' derives from the Norman-French ''Romance'', referring to the far-fetched [[w:Romance (heroic literature)|tales]] of Medieval literature. It became a household word for empty hypocritical talk or [[wikt:cant|cant]] in the first decade of the 20th century thanks to its regular use by the journalist [[w:D. P. Moran|D. P. Moran]] in ''The Leader''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/311|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/313|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment:
Created page with "[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=318]]
==Annotations== ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="ba..."

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=319]]
==Annotations== '''''Entente cordiale'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Cordial agreement''.Gifford (1988) 360.
Thornton (1968) 286. The ''[[w:Entente cordiale|Entente cordiale]]'' was a series of agreements signed on 8 April 1904 between France and the United Kingdom. '''perfidious Albion'''{{spaces|5}}A translation of the perennial French lament, ''Perfide Albion!'' See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/311|311.37]]. '''''Conspuez les Français'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''Down with the French''.Gifford (1988) 360. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/311|311.37]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/315|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/317|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
{{subject page |parent=Wikijunior |description=These [[Wikijunior]] books are for those at a [[Wikibooks:Reading Levels|pre-reader reading level]]. |namespace=Wikijunior }}<noinclude> <!-- CATEGORIES AND INTERWIKIS HERE -->
</noinclude>

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=328]]
==Annotations== '''chanting the introit in ''Epiphania Domini'' which beginneth ''Surge, illuminare'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') The [[w:Introit|Introit]] is the entrance chant in the [[w:Roman Rite|Roman Rite]] of the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still in use in the Catholic Church in 1904. ''Epiphania Domini'' (''The Epiphany of Our Lord'') is the Mass for the [[w:Epiphany_(holiday)|Epiphany of Our Lord]], which fell on 6 January. The introit, however, does not begin with the words ''Surge, illuminare''.Gifford (1988) 377.
Thornton (1968) 301. Those are the opening words of the Lesson (First Reading), which is Isaiah 60:1-6:[http://www.archive.org/stream/MissaleRomanum1603#page/n167/mode/1up ''Missale Romanum 1603''.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''Isaiah 60:1-6'''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2060;1-6&version=VULGATE Bible Gateway.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Surge, illuminare Hierusalem: quia venit lumen tuum et gloria Domini super te orta est.'' ''Quia ecce tenebrae operient terram, et caligo populos. Super te autem orietur Dominus, et gloria eius in te videbitur.'' ''Et ambulabunt gentes in lumine tuo, et reges in splendore ortus tui.'' ''Leva in circuitu oculos tuos, et vide: omnes isti congregati sunt, venerunt tibi. Filii tui de longe venient: et filiae tuae in latere sugent.'' ''Tunc videbis, et afflues: et mirabitur et dilatabitur cor tuum, quando conversa fuerit ad te multitudo maris, fortitudo gentium venerit tibi.'' ''Inundatio camelorum operiet te, dromedariae Madian et Efa. Omnes de Sabba venient, aurum et thus deferentes: et laudem Domino annunciantes.'' | ''Arise, shine. O Jerusalem; for thy light is come, and the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee.'' ''For, behold, the darkness shall cover the earth, and gross darkness the people: but the LORD shall arise upon thee, and his glory shall be seen upon thee.'' ''And the Gentiles shall come to thy light, and kings to the brightness of thy rising.'' ''Lift up thine eyes round about, and see: all they gather themselves together, they come to thee: thy sons shall come from far, and thy daughters shall be nursed at thy side.'' ''Then thou shalt see, and flow together, and thine heart shall fear, and be enlarged; because the abundance of the sea shall be converted unto thee, the forces of the Gentiles shall come unto thee.'' ''The multitude of camels shall cover thee, the dromedaries of Midian and Ephah; all they from Sheba shall come: they shall bring gold and incense; and they shall shew forth the praises of the LORD.'' |} '''the gradual ''Omnes'' which saith ''de Saba venient'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') The [[w:Gradual|Gradual]] is a responsorial chant in the [[w:Roman Rite|Roman Rite]] of the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still in use in the Catholic Church in 1904. It is sung after the Lesson (First Reading) and before the [[w:Sequence_(poetry)|Sequence]].Gifford (1988) 377.
Thornton (1968) 301-302. In the Mass for the Feast of the Epiphany, the Gradual is based on Isaiah 60:6, 1 and Matthew 2:2:[http://www.archive.org/stream/MissaleRomanum1603#page/n167/mode/1up ''Missale Romanum 1603''.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Gradual'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%2060;1-6&version=VULGATE Isaiah 60.]
[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%202&version=VULGATE Matthew 2.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Omnes de Sabba venient, aurum et thus deferentes: et laudem Domino annunciantes'' ''Surge: illuminare Hierusalem: quia gloria Domini super te orta est'' ''Alleluia, alleluia:'' ''Vidimus stellam eius in Oriente: et venimus cum muneribus adorare Dominum alleluia.'' | ''All they from Sheba shall come: they shall bring gold and incense; and they shall shew forth the praises of the LORD.'' ''Arise, shine, O Jerusalem; for the glory of the LORD is risen upon thee.'' ''Alleluia, alleluia:'' ''We have seen his star in the east, and are come with gifts to worship the LORD alleluia.'' |} '''''Adiutorium nostrum in nomine Domini'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Our help is in the name of the Lord''.Gifford (1988) 377.
Thornton (1968) 302. See the [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/326|following page]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/324|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/326|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=329]]
==Annotations== ['''''Adiutorium nostrum'''''] '''... ''Et cum spiritu tuo'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') These four lines are the standard [[w:responsory|responsory]] that precedes the various blessings in the [[w:Roman Ritual|Roman Ritual]]:Gifford (1988) 377.
Thornton (1968) 302. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Rituale Romanum'''''[http://www.archive.org/stream/ritualeromanumpa00cath#page/314/mode/1up ''Rituale Romanum'' 314.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''V:''' ''Our help is in the name of the Lord.'' '''R:''' ''Who made Heaven and Earth.'' '''V:''' ''The Lord be with you.'' '''R:''' ''And with your spirit.'' | '''V:''' ''Adiutorium nostrum in nomine Domini.'' '''R:''' ''Qui fecit cælum et terram.'' '''V:''' ''Dominus vobiscum.'' '''R:''' ''Et cum spiritu tuo.'' |} '''And he laid his hands upon that he blessed...'''{{spaces|5}}''And he laid his hands upon those things which he blessed...''. Here, ''[[wikt:that#Pronoun|that]]'' is the relative pronoun, used archaically, with ellipsis of the antecedent, to refer to a plurality of things. See the Oxford English Dictionary: '''that''', ''pron.''2 '''I. 3. a.'''[http://www.oed.com/ Oxford English Dictionary.] (Access required.) '''''Deus, cuius verbo santificantur omnia ... per Christum Dominum nostrum'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''O God, by whose word all things are made holy, pour down your blessing on these your creations : and grant that whoever shall make use of them, with gratitude and in accordance with your law and your will, may, by calling on your most holy name, receive at your instigation health of body and protection of soul, through Christ our Lord.''Gifford (1988) 378.
Thornton (1968) 302. This is the ''Benedictio Pro Re Quacumque'' (''Blessing for Anything''), which is given in some editions of the ''[[w:Roman Ritual|Rituale Romanum]]'' as a general blessing for use in circumstances where none of the standard blessings would be suitable.[http://www.archive.org/stream/cihm_48368#page/n265/mode/2up ''Compendium Ritualis Romani'' 247-248.] In this case, however, there ''are'' suitable blessings that could have been used to bless ''the viands and the beverages'': for example, ''Benedictio ad Quodcumque Comestibile'' (''Blessing for Anything Edible'')[http://www.archive.org/stream/cihm_48368#page/n179/mode/2up ''Compendium Ritualis Romani'' 165.] ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/325|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/327|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=331]]
==Annotations== '''''éclat'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''brilliance of success''. As a naturalized English word, ''[[wikt:éclat|éclat]]'' is often left unitalicized. '''Messrs Jacob ''agus'' Jacob'''{{spaces|5}}(''Irish'') ''agus'' is the Irish for ''and''. [[w:Jacob's|W. & R. Jacob & Company, Limited]] was a company of biscuit manufacturers that began life as a home bakery in [[w:Waterford|Waterford]] in 1850, expanding to Dublin two years later. The company was formally established in 1885. The Jacobs were a Quaker family. ''[[wikt:Messrs|Messrs]]'' is a plural form of Mr, derived from the French ''messieurs''. It is chiefly used in commerce. '''''Visszontlátásra, kedvés barátom! Visszontlátásra'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Hungarian'') ''Goodbye, my dear friend! Goodbye!''Gifford (1988) 380.
Thornton (1968) 304. The correct form is: ''[[wikt:viszontlátásra|Viszontlátásra]], [[wikt:kedves|kedves]] [[wikt:barát|barátom]]! Viszontlátásra!'' ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/327|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/329|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=332]]
==Annotations== '''''missa pro defunctis'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Mass for the Dead'', or [[w:Requiem|Requiem Mass]].Gifford (1988) 381. '''''débris'''''{{spaces|5}}(''French'') ''[[wikt:débris|rubble]]'', ''wreckage'', ''scattered remains of destroyed buildings''. ''Débris'' is now a naturalized English word; it is usually spelt ''[[wikt:debris|debris]]'', without the accent and without italics. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/328|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/330|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=333]]
==Annotations== '''''Abba!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Syriac-Greek'') ''Father''.Gifford (1988) 381. The [[wikt:Abba|word]] is chiefly used as an invocation to God as the Heavenly Father. '''''Adonai!'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Hebrew'') ''My Lord''.Gifford (1988) 381. This term is usually substituted for the [[wikt:Tetragrammaton|Tetragrammaton]] [[wikt:YHWH|YHWH]], the sacred name of the God, which Jews consider too sacred to be uttered. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Cyclops/329|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Nausicaa/331|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Dae5y!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 18:49, 26 November 2011 (UTC)

==Removing note on raw meat hazards== Just removed the following paragraph:
:"It is very likely that one can contract either pathogenic E Coli infection or salmonellosis since even the best ground beef is a composite of many different slaughtered animals, increasing the risk incrementally."
The first part ("It is very likely that...") is pretty absurd; yes, there is the risk, but if contamination was "very likely", I believe we'd have an ambulance awaiting in front of every restaurant that serves this dish. :-)
The second part ("ground beef is a composite...") might be true in some countries, but in others it is not. Where I live, the majority of ground beef (high or low quality) one can buy comes from a single piece of meat, from a single animal. Besides, this paragraph was superfluous since the standard "raw-meat" template (which is much more reasonable in content) has been added to the page. [[User:Miguelito Vieira|Miguelito Vieira]] ([[User talk:Miguelito Vieira|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Miguelito Vieira|contribs]]) 19:20, 26 November 2011 (UTC)
{{book category header}} [[Category:Wikijunior]]

====2.5 Function==== ----
'''2.5.1 Explain the role of producers, consumers and decomposers in the ecosystem.''' :* Producers: Organisms that use sunlight energy to create food are called Photoautotrophs :* Consumers: They eat other organisms to obtain energy. For example, herbivores will eat the plants, then the herbivores are eaten by carnivores or omnivores :* Decomposers: Obtain energy from breakdown of dead organic matter. They are key to the nitrogen cycle. They convert ammonia from decomposing organisms and excretory waste into nitrites and ultimately into nitrates. Plants then take nitrates through their Root systems
'''2.5.2 Describe photosynthesis and respiration in terms of inputs, outputs and energy transformations.''' :* Photosynthesis (CO2 + H2O --> C6H12O6 + O2) Inputs: Carbon Dioxide & Water Outputs: Glucose & Oxygen Transformations: Producers transform light energy (from the sun) into chemical energy
:* Respiration (C6H12O6 + O2 --> CO2 + H2O + Heat) Inputs: Glucose & Oxygen Outputs: Carbon Dioxide & Water Transformations: Chemical Energy turns into Heat
'''2.5.3 Describe and explain the transfer and transformation of energy as it flows through an ecosystem.'''
- Explain pathways of incoming solar radiation incident on the ecosystem including: :* loss of radiation through reflection and absorption :* conversion of light to chemical energy :* loss of chemical energy from one trophic level to another :* efficiencies of transfer :* overall conversion of light to heat energy by an ecosystem :* re-radiation of heat energy to the atmosphere.
- Construct and analyse simple energy-flow diagrams illustrating the movement of energy through ecosystems, including the productivity of the various trophic levels. :* Storages = Boxes :* Flows of energy or productivity = Arrows
'''2.5.4 Describe and explain the transfer and transformation of materials as they cycle within an ecosystem.'''
:* Processes involving the transfer and transformation of carbon, nitrogen and water as they cycle within an ecosystem should be described, and the conversion of organic and inorganic storage noted where appropriate. Construct and analyse flow diagrams of these cycles
'''2.5.5 Define the terms Gross productivity, net productivity, primary productivity and secondary productivity.'''
:* Gross Productivity: The <u>total gain</u> in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time, which could be through photosynthesis in primary producers or absorption in consumers. :* Net Productivity: The gain in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time remaining after allowing for respiratory losses (R). Other metabolic losses may take place, but these may be ignored when calculating and defining net productivity for the purpose of this course. :* Primary Productivity: The gain by producers in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time. This term could refer to either gross or net primary productivity. :* Secondary Productivity: The biomass gained by heterotrophic organisms, through feeding and absorption, measured in units of mass or energy per unit area per unit time.
Productivity is production per unit time.
'''2.5.6 Define the terms and calculate the values of both gross primary productivity (GPP) and net primary productivity (NPP) from given''' '''data.'''
:* Gross Primary Productivity: The total gain in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time fixed by photosynthesis in green plants. :* Net Primary Productivity: The gain by producers in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time remaining after allowing for respiratory losses (R). This is potentially available to consumers in an ecosystem.
Use the equation NPP = GPP – R, where R = respiratory loss
'''2.5.7 Define the terms and calculate the values of both gross secondary productivity (GSP) and net secondary productivity (NSP) from''' '''given data.'''
:* Gross Secondary Productivity: The total gain by consumers in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time through absorption. :* Net Secondary Productivity: The gain by consumers in energy or biomass per unit area per unit time remaining after allowing for respiratory losses (R).
Use the equation NSP = GSP – R, where R = respiratory loss Use the equation GSP = food eaten – fecal loss {{BookCat}}

page.title: IB Environmental Systems and Societies/Detection and monitoring of pollution

revision.text:
====5.2 Detection and Monitoring of Pollution==== ----
'''5.2.1 Describe two direct methods of monitoring pollution.'''
-air pollution- :* measure the acidity of rain water to determine levels of :* measure CO2, CO, or NOx levels in the atmosphere using a gas sensor :* measure particulate matter suspended in the atmosphere -soil pollution- :* conduct tests for nitrates and phosphates according to the test manufacturer’s instructions :* measure the level of organic matter in the soil -water pollution- :* nitrate and phosphate tests :* fecal coliform tests :* tests for heavy metals
'''5.2.2 Define the term biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and explain how this indirect method is used to assess pollution levels in water.'''
:* Biochemical Oxygen Demand: A measure of the amount of dissolved oxygen required to break down the organic material in a given volume of water through aerobic biological activity. high BOD indicates there are many organisms using oxygen for respiration low BOD indicates relatively few organisms needing oxygen for respiration high BOD = low DO levels = high pollutant levels, especially nitrate & phosphate low BOD = high DO levels = low pollutant levels
'''5.2.3 Describe and explain an indirect method of measuring pollution levels using a biotic index.''' :* We can measure pollution levels 2 different ways: we can measure the pollution itself directly, or we can use some other factor that is correlated to pollution levels as an indirect indicator of those pollution levels. :* the Trent Biotic Index uses the presence or absence of 6 key organisms(plecopteran larvae, ephemeropteran larvae, trichopteran larvae, Gammarus, Asellus and tubificids plus red chironomid larvae) to indicate the relative level of pollution in a stream. Advantage: Easy to use, especially for moderately or heavily polluted sites. Disadvantages: not specific enough, doesn’t fully account for habitat quality
:* We can also use “abiotic factors that change as a result of the pollutant” to indirectly test the pollution levels such as dissolved oxygen (DO) or BOD levels of the water Indicator species are those species that are present either only in polluted areas or only in unpolluted areas. For example… o freshwater shrimp, o freshwater mussels, o stonefly nymphs, o caddisfly larvae, o rat-tailed maggot o sludge worms in polluted water, o peppered moth wing color (predominantly black indicates high levels of soot and particulate matter in the air; predominantly light grey indicates relatively particulate-free air), o Gammarus - small crustaceans that are sensitive to different salinity levels, o Asellus - another small freshwater crustacean, which is relatively tolerant of pollution, and therefore an indicator of polluted sites {{BookCat}}
All of us are running blind.

page.title: IB Environmental Systems and Societies/Topic 1: Systems and models

revision.text:
====1.1. Systems and Models==== ----
It is essential that the systems approach is used throughout this course. This approach identifies the elements of the systems, and examines the relationships and processes that link these elements into a functioning entity. This topic may be best viewed therefore as a theme to be used in the delivery of the other topics, rather than as an isolated teaching topic. The topic identifies some of the underlying principles that can be applied to living systems, from the level of the individual up to that of the whole biosphere. It would therefore be helpful to describe and analyse the systems addressed in the terms laid out in this topic (wherever possible). The systems approach also emphasizes the similarities between environmental systems, biological systems and artificial entities such as transport and communication systems. This approach stresses that there are concepts, techniques and terms that can be transferred from one discipline (such as ecology) to another (such as engineering). {{BookCat}}
